151266138.review:
Starting with the pros:

-One of the most visually appealing games I've ever played.
-Rich and engaging story and characters.
-Quality voice acting.
-Game play is good at best and inoffensive at worst.

Now the cons:

-Each chapter(whether good or bad) tend to overstay there welcome, and end up becoming tedious.
-Camera is awkward and slow, but not the worst.
-Crashed a few times, but not enough to be concerned.

-Quick Note:
You will have to modify the game files if you want the game to have better performance and to active or add the additional content(The DLC costumes and American McGee's Alice)

Overall ranking and closing thoughts:

7/10
8 or 9/10 if I'm being biased.

This is one of my favorite games, even with its problems.
I think it's one that anyone who's a fan of 3D Platformers or edgy games with dark humor(Applies more to American McGee's Alice) will enjoy.
I hope you enjoyed this review, and I'll probably post another one whenever I feel like it.

See ya.

150048519.review: Alice has become one of my all time favs. The art direction is on point & game dives deep into mental health & other dark topics which I loved. There's plenty of action but this is a platformer the majority of the time, keep that in mind. This game is not easy by any means but it is worth it to watch how the events of that night that changed Alice's whole life played out..

150048355.review:
This review is easily one of the hardest I have ever had to make. I started this game and played the first few hours with the immediate thought "I think this is my new favorite game." It is so SO close to being my favorite, but there is just a few too many bugs in this game. There are other aspects too though that keep it from being in my #1, even though as time goes on I like it more and more. For the first time in one of my steam reviews, I'm going to break up this section by listing my pros and cons.

Pros:
-The gameplay in this game is SO satisfying and addicting. I could seriously play it forever. The mechanics are probably some of the best I've ever seen given how satisfying each weapon is to play with. Most likely everyone is going to have a favorite weapon, but they all run amazingly. It shocks me that this game received a mediocre reception upon release given that it's one of the best I've played. I suppose that first game must have been genre-defining or something for people to have not given this one the love and attention it deserved.
-This game is drop dead gorgeous. It hasn't aged much at all. I cannot believe it is 10+ years old, it looks better than a lot of the stuff that releases nowadays. This game instantly sticks in my mind for all the landscapes being varied and eye-catching. The animations too have a special level of attention to detail that I appreciated. The way Alice plays, idles, and interacts with people and enemies particularly sticks out in my mind. I also love the character designs, they're all so interesting and a bit grotesque, even outside of wonderland. This game will always stay with me for being the perfect blend of beautiful memorable aesthetics mixed with different types and levels of horror. We need more games that go for distinctive styles like this, I miss them desperately. I'd love more games that go for a style like this rather than striving for hyper-realism.
-The gameplay has variation in a way that feels immensely satisfying. I know some people did not like all of the puzzles or the song games, but I didn't mind them. However, I do admit, that I did start skipping a lot of puzzles (chess, doll puzzle) toward the end because I was so excited about the story I did not want to be held up with any of the mini-games so I could finish the game. Certain forms of gameplay variation stick in my mind for their excellence (specifically the gameplay after eating cake was so fun and so satisfying). If I'm talking gameplay alone, this is easily the best I've played.
-The story of Alice: Madness Returns is really interesting. Like, addictingly interesting. I was so fascinated by the story I could not stop playing because I wanted to know what was going to happen. Make sure you get this game when you have a lot of free time because if you are like me, it will consume your life. I will say after playing the full game, the story is not perfect but I feel like it's expertly crafted, well told, and resonant to a lot of people. I will not spoil anything, but all I'm going to say is that while the twist at the end wasn't executed perfectly, it had enough setup and payoff to not ruin the experience for me. I'll go more into my thoughts about it in the cons.

Cons:
-This game is BUGGY. I thought people might have been slightly exaggerating or there were compatibility issues, but it is just a game problem. There were multiple times that the game would crash as I was starting it up or would freeze on a loading screen. Eventually, I looked to the community forum for help. To stop the loading bug, I would need to uninstall and reinstall the game, meaning I would have to repeatedly uninstall and reinstall the game just to finish the dang thing. I must have uninstalled and reinstalled this game over 10 times just to get it to work. There were an abundance of minor bugs I encountered too. Keep in mind that these were some of my problems in my play through. Some people have even complained that the game is so buggy they can't even play it anymore if they ever could.
-If people in your community forum are telling players ways to code the game so it will look and play better, that's a problem. For example, originally this game ran at 30 FPS. The community suggests changing the game code to 60 FPS because the game look and play better. While the game did crash the first time I did that, the game looked and played way better after I did that for the rest of the game. I'm not sure if coding higher FPS would risk making the game incompatible for anyone's computer, but 30 FPS made the game look objectively worse for reasons I don't understand. Some mechanics are confusing too. Specifically, having to use focus to use your block attack. It's such a problem for some people they had to go into the code to fix it.
-Most people's issues with Madness come from the fact that it makes a story that was initially morally grey story made into a more black-and-white story. I can't necessarily argue with that but I think that the twist has more weight to it than people give it credit for, even if I have mixed feelings about it myself. Sometimes you can tell a twist was objectively set up and paid off really well and still feel a little meh about the twist. 
-I feel like for many, the biggest issue not related to bugs is that Alice: Madness Returns has a little too many different plot lines and not quite enough room to flush them all out. That in itself is not an issue for me, but I understand wanting certain themes to be explored a little more or more heavily foreshadowed at the very beginning rather than in the middle. I think with just a tiny bit more time and fine-tuning everything could have come together a little better to make it perfect. As is, it's still a banger game though.

I love this game, I truly do, and it deserves to be treated better, both by fans and by the studio that owns the rights to it. Even though I am disappointed about the ultimate fate of the Alice franchise, I 100% recommend this game to anyone who'll listen. It is a genuinely great game that deserves to be loved and celebrated more, don't let it become obsolete. However, if the game does not open or work for you, refund it immediately. Do not wait for the game developers to fix it because it doesn't look like that is an option. Lastly, and I want to make this abundantly clear, I do not blame any of the creators of the game for the game being so buggy. I personally believe the responsibility is on the studio which owns the rights to upkeep the games they own the rights to. American McGee and his team have the utmost love for this game and fought for a port. We are lucky to even have this game on Steam, let alone this game period, because of the people who fought for it. The game is so unbelievably phenomenal that it deserves attention. It is a shame this game ended a little open-ended because I was excited for the third installment after playing this game. I will always mourn the death of Alice Asylum, but there's nothing stopping fans from finishing the story in whatever way they please. We have this game as a sequel to the first. We are lucky for that. Send the creators some love. They deserve to be celebrated for what they accomplished. They do not deserve any harassment for something they ultimately cannot control. EA holds the rights and does not want to continue this franchise. There's nothing we can do about it. If you are upset, you can voice your concerns to EA in a polite, civil manner.
If EA happens to be reading this, hi. I know I might have been a little harsh in this review, but please hear me out on 1 thing. I think it'd be a good idea to allow fans to legally purchase the first Alice game on Steam or as a DLC to the second game. That way you can earn so much money for your work and fans can play the game legally. Please just, consider it.

150047278.review:
Un Hack and Slash toda la extensión de la palabra, con un sistema de combate simple pero adictivo. 

El principal punto fuerte de este juego es sin duda la dirección de arte en los escenarios, enemigos y personajes,  es simplemente brutal al mas mínimo detalle. Desde paisajes oníricos que evocan una calma y belleza envolvente, hasta escenarios sacados de las mas profundas pesadillas de un infante traumatizado con las peores desgracias que puede sufrir un ser humano, Los enemigos sin duda recuerdan a los personajes de la obra de Carrol, mas otros mas que simplemente parecen sacados de algún Silent Hill. 

Con lo que respecta a Alice, su diseño y concepto es mi favorito que se ha hecho para representar a Alice Lidell.

Uno de los pocos puntos flacos que destaco es el control de cámara que en ocasiones es inestable, pero fuera de eso, Alice: Madness Returns es una experiencia que todos los amantes de la fantasía deben probar aunque sea una vez.

Una verdadera lástima que EA no haya querido financiar Alice: Asylum, sin duda, este título tiene mucho potencial para futuras entregas

150040815.review:
Historia turbia y que te coge la mente: 10/10
Jugabilidad hack n slash exquisita, fluida y con lvleo de armas: 10/10
Diseño de niveles hechos con mimo al milímetro: 10/10
Puzzles y minijuegos muy intuitivos y divertidos: 10/10
Enemigos bien diseñados y balanceados, con diferentes ataques: 10/10

Buen guión, buen soundtrack, buen doblaje, lo único "malo" es que es un poco más largo de lo que debería de ser. Y no es muy dificil, por lo que incluso en la dificultad máxima no supone un reto.

Me enamoré de Alice. Le resto un punto por eso.

8/10

150011742.review:
I could write pages upon pages on why this games is bad and why you shouldn't buy it, but I'll spare you the time and give you the condensed version.

According to the game, It took me 14 hours to beat the game. If I had played another game instead of this one, it wouldn't have been too short, nor would it have been too long, but since this is the game I played, the 14 hours I put into it actually felt like a ~40-hour, excruciatingly long, tedious experience. The game is RIDICULOUSLY long for what it offers. It has content for like a 7-8-hour playthrough, which is half of the actual playtime. 

The problems:

The game is an action-platformer. You mainly jump from platform to platform, have some story bits and kill some enemies in between all the jumping and platforming stuff. So far, it sounds completely fine, but what's not fine is that the platforming "puzzles" (for want of a better word) are not hard or challenging at all, they are almost identical with only slight variations, and they make up the majority of the content. They are so dead simple that you don't have to think, you don't have to look around or time your jumps / movements correctly. Because the game is so long, you just do them ad nauseaum until your brain starts to go numb and you start to go insane because of the boredom. Everything is copy-pasted everywhere, only the textures and models look different, but the core of what you have to do is the same everywhere. Them being easy wouldn't be an issue if the game weren't as stretched out, or if they weren't repetitive, but they are.

Which brings me to the chapters / levels. At the beginning of each chapter, everything looks beautiful and mesmerizing (the art style is one of the few strengths of the game, the game still looking good to this day), but since every chapter is longer than it needs to, the glamour will start to fall off sooner rather than later, and everything will just blend together in your head because of the copy-paste nature of everything. The story bits happen very sporadically. Sometimes you jump around mindlessly for 1-2 hours before the story progresses. The pacing in the game is godawful.

The game also has very few actual puzzles and side-scrolling platforming mini-games. The puzzles are just as easy as the rest of the game (they are mostly sliding puzzles, which take like 5 seconds to solve). The mini-games are the exact same platforming stuff you do in the game, only in 2D. There is no purpose to them other than to pad the game's length. They are completely unnecessary.

To get you out of your numbness, the game will throw some enemies at you here and there. The combat is the only thing in the gameplay that I actually enjoyed despite its flaws. The enemy variety is good, mostly. All of the enemies are unique, they all have their unique ways of dealing with them. The weapon system is creative. All the weapons have their use (again, mostly, because the hobby horse felt totally useless after I got the teapot).

However, I can't walk past the controls. If you want to use either the pepper grinder or the teapot, you have to lock onto your target. Unfortunately, the target-locking, or rather the focus target mechanism is completely broken. Once you have locked onto your target and start moving around, the camera won't follow your character properly. What will end up happening is that both you and your target will end up in the opposite ends of your screen, making you unable to see where the other enemies are. Sometimes you won't be able to see either yourself or the enemy you're targeting, either. To solve this problem, you have to re-focus your target constantly, which is easier said than done when you are surrounded by multiple enemies because target-swapping is also broken. Since the targeting is in the way all the time, it makes you focus on the game less and on the controls more, which is just annoying.

To add insult to injury, the above mentioned broken mechanic is blatantly abused by the developers in two boss fights (one is in chapter 2, the other is in the doll house in chapter 5). What these bosses have in common is that you have to use a ranged weapon to beat them (I guess you can melee them as well, but that way they are much harder), they are not hard to kill by themselves, they just take long. They have these slimes, which look like leeches, spawning around the area. The slimes barely do any damage to you and die in one hit, so they should be barely an inconvenience. But they are not because what they do is totally mess up your targeting because they make it almost impossible to lock onto the bosses because guess what, you can't get rid of them because they respawn until the boss dies. The reason you take damage in these fights is not because the boss mechanics are hard, but because you are too busy fumbling with the controls. Instead of implementing actually interesting and challenging boss mechanics, the developers chose to make two already easy bosses "harder" by abusing the broken focus target system. The purpose of the slimes in these two fights is to mess up your targeting, nothing else. The bosses were not hard to kill, even with the slimes, but the fact that the developers did this is truly ridiculous.


I could also talk about the various bugs / crashes that happen during gameplay, I could also talk about how you can't assign the melee weapons to their own hotkeys in the game's menu, how you can only do this by editing an .ini file, which is on another level of ridiculousness.

All in all, what this game needed was for the developers to cut its length by half, make the platforming harder / swap some of the platforming sections for actual puzzles and fix the targeting system. This way, we could have a much tighter, more enjoyable experience. It's a shame what state the game is in because hidden underneath all the bad stuff is a great game. I really liked the concept, but the execution was very very bad.

I've always loved this game. American McGee's Alice was a fun, dark, goth-y game, but Madness Returns has a solid and disturbing story line.

Downsides with the PC version vs console are noticeable.
For me at least:
       The game almost always crashes when you first boot it up and click Continue.
       If you unplug your headphones mid-game, it freezes and you have to do a hard restart.
       The audio randomly cuts out, usually when you pause the game for too long.
       Alice has a quadruple float-jump, but it doesn't always work and sometimes you only jump a couple of times before falling to your death.
       The controls themselves are wonky, or my left pinky just isn't used to rapidly switching between TAB, CAPS LOCK, SHIFT, and CTRL. I know I can remap the controls, but the other convenient keys are taken.

Overall, I'd still recommend this game. It's a fun, broody experience. I completed the game with only a few facepalms. I just ordered an X-Box controller (I'm exclusively a PS girl) to see if that helps with the gameplay. I'll fight to make this game work on PC, it's worth it.

149682215.review:
Wow, what a beautiful game. Not only does this game look wonderful and run great, (I know it's old but you'd be surprised how poorly optimized most stuff is), but it's also so extremely imaginative and fun! Let me try to list some reasons to play this game, even in the modern market:

- The gameplay is fun and rewarding, not the other way around!
What do I mean by this? Well as far as I'm concerned, tons of modern games love to make playing their game a chore. Not only are the things you can do not very cool, fun, exciting, or whatever else you want to call the gameplay element in question, but most of them have obnoxious cooldowns and/or resources that you have to spend to even use the ability. This game does none of that. The guns are balanced with an overheating system and all your weapon upgrades are gated behind the single resources in the game, teeth (aka the money). It doesn't feel stingy, you can EASILY upgrade all your weapons before the end of the game, and they're all really fun to use and switch between. The jumps/double jumps and the shrinking ability are both extremely useful and don't require any cooldown or any other dumb mechanic to use them, they just work.

- The world is creative and fun to explore!
Even though our games keep getting larger and more sprawling with every release, they often seem to lack depth; at least from my perspective. The maps are large, but every corner is unworthy of exploring. Things look boring, or all too the same, there aren't rewards in the remote corners of the map like you thought there would be, and it's plain and simply just not fun to run around in. Alice is the antithesis of this! Each and every map is beautiful and creative in their own way, reflecting the personality of not only the character we will be addressing in this chapter, but also reflecting how Alice views this person in real life. Each area has a lot of scenery to chew and enjoy, a lot of changing details that are fun to look at, and tons of hidden areas of secret paths that reward you! I know maybe this can sound like a silly compliment to a veteran gamer that's been playing for decades, but modern gaming is so bad at doing what this game did SO WELL that I think it's easy to forget to appreciate these things and point them out. Overall just wonderful design in this, sorry for the essay.

- Rewards, Rewards, REWARDS!!

I don't know how you guys feel about 3D platformers, but I usually get pretty annoyed with the sheer amount of stuff they want you to pick up while navigating the map; and I get even more annoyed when all that crazy stuff I've been collecting has no purpose other than a number on a screen to make me feel like I accomplished something. In Alice, everything you pick up means something. All the memories help you uncover Alice's history and the true intentions and feelings of the characters driving her life along. I even wondered what use there was for collecting one of the items, the bottles, but if you get all of them in an area you unlock extra story content. Very well done; it made me want to find all the hidden areas and extra goodies. Even all the times it was 'just' teeth I was happy because I wanted to upgrade my weapons. Kudos to the collecting aspect of this game, I really didn't think I'd enjoy it as much as I did!

- I'm no idiot, don't treat me like one!

Okay maybe a weird one to bring up but WOW modern gaming makes me feel like a baby. The dialog in so many games feels so obvious and surface level that I get really bored and, often times, just skip much of said dialog because it isn't engaging. Alice does not hold your hand and it doesn't care if you don't understand something. Much like the feeling of consuming old Alice inspired media, this game is cryptic in much (not all) of it's dialog. People speak in odd ways and reference things you may not be privy to and it just hopes you'll pay attention and keep up. Loved that. Thanks to the game for the fun little story, it was actually fun to uncover and figure out and experience. ALSO: there's tons of areas where they introduce completely new gameplay features and they just quickly go "okay here you've played something like this before, just play it" - like they didn't feel the need to do a tutorial for every single thing in the entire game, it's just smart enough to know that I'll press the 7 buttons available to me and figure it out. UGH THANK FUCK.

- Not too easy, not too difficult.

Tons of games want to be either the most relaxed thing you've ever experienced or they want you to sweat bullets and beat your head against a wall until you get it. This game is just right in it's difficulty. Nothing is too difficult and the auto-saves are close enough to where you'll die to not make it a huge deal. There is ONE enemy that I am near positive was supposed to be like a difficulty cap for players, to like make you get better before moving on I think (?), but WOW he's actually really annoying and I hate him a lot BUT that being said he wasn't impossible and you'll probably only die like once or twice to one when you're fighting it. Overall though this game was great about how difficult it wanted to be and, at the end of the day, it just wanted to assist you in using the mechanics to play the game and have fun and that's a huge plus in my book.

- Damn bro, you need more? Just go play the thing.

Nah seriously, did any of you even make it this far? You're reading reviews for a 12+ year old game?..... Nice. actually.

I mean IDK that they're perfect but they work well and they feel seemless and I really appreciate their inclusion. Game feels good, just has good game-feel (if you don't know what I mean I have no way to explain, you just gotta play more games and get that game feel kinda shit down you know?). Just good. 149673297.review:
If I play this game in xbox 360 I have an achievement!
https://www.xboxachievements.com/game/alice-madness-returns/achievements/

Why not has in steam?

The Windows version is locked to 30FPS, although there is an easy fix to put it into 144FPS. Simply go into the right click -> Properties menu, local files -> browse. From there go into AliceGame -> Config -> open up DefaultEngine.ini and look for the first place it says 

MinSmoothedFrameRate=60
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=144

That's it and you're good to go. One thing to mention is that, at least on Steam Deck, there are some lighting glitches present. It's not overly distracting but a few of the flashes may cause issues for some people.

149661896.review: A great game from a time when creativity and artistry mattered in the finished product. A time when most games were visually distinctive from the next. Alice: Madness Returns, the sequel to American McGee's Alice, is dripping with a visual style that is all its own. Locations range from beautiful to twisted, the combat is visceral and satisfying with unique weapons you can upgrade. The platforming at times forces you to think or look before you leap, leaving you feeling accomplished, and there's plenty of extras to unlock as you play through the game. Now that every game has hyper-realistic and samey graphics, or regurgitated concepts, this one stands out as a shining example of what games used to be. Fun. If any of that sounds good to you, don't even hesitate to buy the game and delve into the Madness for yourself!

And of course, both games are excellent. Fairly simple gameplay wise, each pretty reflective of the decade they were made; But what sets Alice apart is the sheer creativity on display. Every level feels different from the last, and is rich in detail. They're both well written, and turn a concept that should be pretty cringe, into a game that not only still feels fresh, but is very charming, and at times horrific.

It's a massive shame that EA killed Alice Asylum, and is another reminder of the company's boundless greed and stupidity.

149432131.review:
If steam had an option to give a "mixed" review I would. I recommend playing this game at a heavy discount, please do not give more than 3 dollars to EA games.

First of all I don't blame American McGee I know EA had some part in fucking this game up which could have been otherwise a masterpiece.

I read somewhere EA said McGee has 3 months or the game doesn't get released.

Compared to the first game, the first game had a way better soundtrack, way more enemy variety, more weapon variety, characters seemed more fun, bosses, etc.

Levels in the first game were all unique, each level had a story to tell just by walking through it. However the second game because Alice can triple jump this creates lazy map design. So they copy and paste floating platforms all over the map which drags the chapters out for hours at a time. 

Other things the first game did better when Alice shrunk she became the size of an ant and you had to explore a whole giant world.

Second game when alice shrinks it's just to go into a hole to collect a memory (in game collectible) nothing really exciting.

The second game has way less enemies and they copy and paste baby dolls all over every level which makes the levels feel less unique. 

The first game has 9 chapters, each chapter has 2 to 6 subchapters in them and each sub chapter feels new and refreshing to explore through.

The second game has 6 chapters and from start to finish they look and play exactly the same and drag out over 2+ hours.  The only chapter that felt the most finished was the queen of hearts chapter which I read was the only section of the game that was 100% done at the end of the 3 month deadline. 


Again it's a great game but I blame EA for the copy and pasted map design, the lack of enemy variety, the boring soundtrack and the bland levels, boring NPCs, etc. I know American McGee would have wanted to do better.

Mi opinión hacia Alice Madness Returns es que tiene narrativa oscura y la ambientación son impresionantes. Sin embargo, la jugabilidad pero tiene algunos fallos como: 

1. Repetitividad: El juego puede volverse repetitivo en cuanto a las mecánicas de juego, ya que a lo largo del juego te enfrentas a situaciones similares una y otra vez.

2. Problemas técnicos: Caídas de velocidad de fotogramas, errores gráficos, bloqueos ocasionales del juego y sobretodo el querer guardar partida. Estos es unos de los problemas que pueden variar.

3. Curva de dificultad: Que la curva de dificultad del juego es desigual, con secciones que pueden resultar extremadamente difíciles y otras que son bastante fáciles.

4. Cámara: La cámara del juego a veces se hace problemática, lo que hace dificultar la navegación y el combate en muchas situaciones.

Debido a estos fallos no le quita que se le pueda dar oportunidad para pasar unas buenas horas de entretenimiento.

Pd: Alice Asylum tenia pinta de haber sido increíble, es una lastima que haya sido cancelado.

148947565.review:
Alice Madness Returns is an action platformer masterpiece from American McGee.

Inspired by the fabulous universe of Alice in Wonderland, the game has a sumptuous artistic direction, between the sublime and the nightmarish.

Traumatized by a tragic fire that decimated her family, Alice Liddell suffers hallucinations, sometimes dreamlike, sometimes psychotic. The poor young girl wants to know the truth about this terrible incident.

The real world is all poverty and sadness, and Alice tries to disentangle the truth from the lies about her youth and her present.

The script is amusing and well written.
The narration offers a curious mix of genres.
Some tirades are full of puns, and dialogues are theatrical and poetic.
Several characters use double language, and sometimes give rise to very funny moments.

The heroine has a whole arsenal at her disposal, which can be improved.

Here are the weapons that Alice will find during her journey:
- The Vorpal Blade, a sharp knife dealing fast attacks
- The Pepper Grinder, a sort of machine gun
- The Hobby Horse, a kind of heavy hammer
- The Clockwork Bomb, an explosive with a timer
- The Teapot Cannon, a powerful gun that shoots one projectile at a time

Some of these weapons have a dual purpose and allow you to progress through the levels, giving the possibility of activating specific platforms or mechanisms.

Alice also has special abilities:
In addition to being able to glide over short distances, the young heroine can dash to avoid her enemies, shrink to reach areas with a tiny entrance, or use a sort of sixth sense to see otherwise invisible platforms.

Miss Liddell is well equipped to deal with evil creatures.
The bestiary is particularly well stocked.
The monsters are as numerous as they are original and each fights in a different way.
Each critter has a weak point, making it more vulnerable to a particular weapon.
Note also the presence of gigantic bosses. At least compared to Alice...

Various objects litter the levels.
Teeth are scattered everywhere, they are used to exchange for weapon upgrades, but it takes several hundred to do so.
Various souvenir items can be collected, they help Alice remember various events. 
Pink flowers dot the levels, they allow the heroine to heal herself if she enters them in shrunken mode. 
You need to have a good sense of observation to find well-hidden objects and secret passages.

Wonderland is beautifully illustrated and laid out.
The maps are teeming with details, and should be contemplated.
All levels are peppered with puzzles and creatures to fight.
Alice wears a different dress depending on the chapter, each one being sumptuous.

Small personal paragraph.
I hesitated for a long time to buy this game.
However, I always kept an eye on it.
I have always been fascinated by first its aesthetic, then its storyline.
The game has been delisted and relisted several times on Steam, which makes it unusual.
If you've read this far, you know that this game is one of my favorites.

Alice Madness Returns is an exceptional game in many ways.
Magnificent, ingenious, fun, captivating and endearing, few games can boast of being so successful in so many areas.
A sequel, named Alice Asylum, was abandoned by EA.
Rather an anticlimax, for a game of this quality.

This game is horrible and you should not buy it. The villain of the game has been sexually assaulting and trafficking children, and the game handles that subject horribly. It is a ham-fisted portrayal of the issue, and utterly disgusting.

Mechanically the game is mediocre, and everything it does has been done better by some other game. Visually the game limps along, utterly failing to improve upon the art style of the previous game in the series. The quality of the entire game, both mechanics and art, is inconsistent and not worth the time spent to get to a revolting plot reveal.

The game designers seem to have felt that sending the player through the crotch of a giant baby doll, just before revealing that the plot is about the sexual abuse of children, was somehow good symbolism, but it's just crude and revolting.

148523090.review:
Sadly, I want to recommend this game but I can't given how frustrating my experience with the stability has been.

Overall: 6/10. I would rate it to 9 if the game weren't so unstable.

The best thing about it: aesthetic win (alice + goth = my two favorite things)

- Decent gameplay loop. Fun weapons for the most part. Platforming is generally fun. Hysteria mode is rad!

- Story is whimsical. There is some subtext and intertext I find interesting, but that lies deep within a thick layer of nonsense, which is what I would expect from an Alice in Wonderland offshoot.

The worst thing about it: Stability. I had crashes constantly, nothing works to fix them. I can't even alt - tab into task manager and close it down manually either. I have to fully restart my computer because the loading screens are often an infinite glitch.

VERDICT: Sadly, no. I love a lot about the game but the stability is ass. If it had a windowed mode built in I would be happy, but it offers no solution to the constant crashes. 148429826.review: I know this may seem like an "unfair" review to be writing after I inform you that I'm only two hours into gameplay, but within these two hours, I have fallen in love with what I believe to be an amazing game. Maybe it's because I love anything that lies within the horror genre, or maybe it's because I genuinely believe this is a great twist on the beloved story "Alice in Wonderland." Regardless, this is a game I can confidently say I will be playing as much as I please, which will probably be an unnecessary amount of times, and truly enjoy. And this is evident considering all the screenshots I've taken of this game so far— screenshots that take up half, maybe more, of my gallery on Steam. First and foremost, this game features a wonderful story that, from the start, reels in players. In this game, Alice is a young orphan girl who, at some point in her life, found care in a psychiatric clinic. It is clear that Wonderland serves as some form of escapism for her trauma and past, but unfortunately, Wonderland is not the beautiful world we know of. Playing as Alice, you fight evil creatures and meet characters that we know from the original story, like Hatter and Cheshire Cat. For some, I'm sure this game is just plain creepy and that there's little to no beauty in the world of Wonderland, but from the little details of flowers you find roaming about to Alice herself, I find this game rather alluring in a beautiful sense. I am so, so excited to play through the entirety of this game, and I would highly recommend this to anyone that's considering buying it.

148280697.review:
What's that one title that lives in your head [i]rent-free?[/i] For me, it's this one.

I was a child who grew up with a rather evident obsession for everything related to Alice in Wonderland: Her world of all wonder and oddities. I would often imagine myself running across the mossy forest, hopping through the beams of sunlight, and chasing down a rabbit in a suit, seemingly in a hurry. I would write my own stories with different twists, varied characters of the same caliber, and additional endings. What if I tumbled down a rabbit hole? Or a magical well? I would have the wildest dreams of going on all those expeditions and adventures with the friends of my own imagination.

Then, I slowly hopped onto the train of young adulthood, assembling a more [i]gothic[/i] alter persona (whatever that means?) My interests remained as they were; however, they gained new and more fascinating dimensions. I loved Tim Burton's take on the story of Alice, for instance, and fell in love with the other works he had to offer. I loved the cabaret-like imagery from the 19th century, circus-related looks from the 1910s, fantastic realms of different times, and [i]everything with stripes[/i]. So, as you can also imagine, my first encounter with the game, Alice: Madness Returns, awakened pure madness in my 13-year-old brain! It had creepy dolls, underwater themes, fantastic realms, incredible costume designs (with striped socks!), and a witty, smoky-eyed protagonist with a troubled past. How edgy, am I right? Don't laugh, though- my teenage self was dying to be like her. To this day, almost 10 years later, I still quite like her! 

So yeah, that's my story. I don't know how many times I beat the game or at least booted it up for comfort since then. I know the controls are wonky, and the port is kinda bad ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014521889]which has a fix right here.[/url]) But it holds so many dear memories that I always come back. 
So, thank you, American McGee, and everyone else who worked on all the projects of the merchandise! 

I am devasted to hear that the Asylum project got canceled, by the way. I haven't got over it. But that's okay...I guess...

148259419.review:
I have a love/hate relationship with this game. The original game which isn't included is an absolute masterpiece. Even though the original is dated, it still has so much originality and is very whimsical as well as atmospheric. Alice Madness Returns has some beautiful imagery, but also has some horribly ugly imagery like the town areas where everyone looks atrociously ugly. 

The biggest problem with the game is how boring it is. While the levels do have some cool imagery and graphics, a lot of it is copy and paste. The levels are long and tedious and the chapters feel like they drag on forever. You will fight a lot of the same enemies over and over again. There are some chapter specific enemies, but you run into the same standard black ooze/doll part enemies in every chapter. There is also only 4 weapons, which all get pretty boring after awhile. The upgrades offer nothing more than attack damage and a different skin for the weapons. 


*spoilers ahead*

I'm not a big fan of the story. Madness returns adds a sexual assault story line which wasn't implied in the original. The original game was Alice going mad from a house fire that killed both her parents. Madness returns changes the fire story quite a bit. The game also gives Alice a sister that she didn't have in the original. So quite a few changes. 

I don't feel this game is worth a thumbs down, but I don't feel it's a thumbs up either. It's just kind of mediocre. Thumbs up I guess, because I don't feel it warrants a full thumbs down.

146744171.review: Amazing game with graphics that have aged well considering it came out over a decade ago. The story is great and while there are some flaws, it's amazing. Alice is a wonderful protagonist and is relatable and while she is a female protagonist she is never sexualized. The domains in the game are beautiful, always managing to take your breath away with its' amazing settings and cutscenes. The cutscenes are unlike any other I have seen. They have a unique style and look amazing with great animation. The problems I do have with the game are how short it is, how annoying some of the platforming is, and how long the domains are. While I did say I didn't like how short the game was at the same time the domains sometimes stretch on for far too long. The game was originally planned to have more domains and I felt that the addition of those domains could have helped solve this problem. Overall, while this game is not perfect it is very lovable and beautiful. There is no other game I have connected to as deeply as I have this game.

145601033.review:
★★☆☆☆ Okay!

[h1]Action[/h1]

Alice: Madness Returns is a Action Platformer Adventure game which is a sequel of the first Alice game (American McGee's Alice).

The story is about Alice who is back in action, but is still haunted by her past. The scene with her house burning with her family in the first game keeps on haunting her in this game. Gameplay wise the game is a 3D platformer with Super Mario style platforming sections. In this game Alice have a 4 double jumping ability with a leviate ability after each jump. With this mechanic I feel the game has stretched its platform all over the place so the world feels kinda empty. As for the combat; you get 2 melee weapons and 2 ranged weapons. The Vorpal Blade, a fast style weapon which uses small swipes to take of the enemies for you. The Horse Thing, I giant horse head on a stick Alice uses to deal heavy damage with slow attack speed. The Teapot, basically a grenade launcher, and The Peppergrinder, which is basically a machine gun. The combat runs fluid but may be interrupted from time to time because of the camera not willing to work together with you.

If you like platformers and don't expect anything exceptional or deep, this game might be okay buy. Also if you liked the original game, this has very same feel in it. Otherwise, I would skip this one.

145558151.review:
Finally, after all this years I was able to play and finish this game. I have to say my expectations grew to (six) impossible standards in my head, but it somehow was up to my wildest dreams.

I mean, it's a really janky game. The combat camera is absolutely terrible and locking on an enemy was a sureway to getting killed. It also overstays its welcome a little and every chapter could have been at least 30 minutes shorter and be better for it.

The narration is also kinda "choppy" and the cutscenes could have been better implemented in the game. Some voice actor are wonderful, but others are terrible.

But good lord what a game! What assault to the senses! As an ex-goth kid, I just loved the aesthetics and music. I stopped at every new section just to appreaciate the details on the levels, enemy designs and costumes. Even with the camera problems, combat was fun and the platforming puzles very satisfying, at least until they star repeating the same gimmicks.

The plot was really good too. I was expecting it to be dark and cruel, but not this dark and cruel! OMG! It goes to places where AAA and AA games don't usually go. This is the territory of itch.io indie games that go head-on on abuse themes.

At first, I didn't understood why there were so many doll heads in the enemies and levels, once you understand what they represent you get horrified.

In other time, I would have restarted inmediatly this game and even try to get 100% items and secrets. I no longer have the patience for that in a game like this (its about 15 hours and it should be at least 4 shorter), but I'm already downloading the artbook so I can experience its magnificent and disturbing aesthetics again.

I used to love the first game but Madness Returns is lacking in so many ways.

The global aesthetic of the game and approach of the story are its strongest parts... But that's it!

-The game design is bad : ultra repetitive battles and platformer without any kind of evolution through the game. 
-You have the feeling of repeating the first level with different skins until the end of the game. 
-The weapons keeps the same move set even when maxed out. Only the the teapot is useful.
-The enemies are almost all the same.
-The story telling gets boring as hell because it's almost non existing, eaten by the ultra stretched gameplay.
-That PC version crashes all the time, it's very annoying.

Alice Madness Returns could have been a great game but suffer from a very bad management. Now I can picture why John Carmack fired American McGee over a bad game/level design disagreement.

144368252.review: In the case of Alice: Madness Returns its beautiful burton-esque aesthetic and melodic score are heavily combated by clunky mechanics,poor level design, and an overall lack luster ending. AMR is a relatively enjoyable experience for the first several hours of the game, but it soon fades away when your jump is blocked by yet another invisible wall, and the level proceeds to go on for an hour longer than it should. The puzzles are void of creativity, And the most creative pieces of the game are copy pasted so much you want to alt-f4 at the sight of them. This game is also severely buggy on modern hardware, and requires ini editing in order to get a cool 60 frames. AMR's largest positive is by far it's aesthetics and visuals, with breathtaking worlds all coming with uniquely stunning outfits for alice. A wonderful score is used to perfectly capture the tone of each level and encounter. Each level has intricately crafted unique enemies, and a relatively fluid combat system, save a little clunkiness for the dodge mechanic. It is my opinion that if you manage to find it on sale, the journey down the rabbit hole may be worth the time, despite the games maddening problems.

144144676.review:
Beautiful, whimsical, and truly disturbing by turns...and sometimes all three at once! Alice's story and style capture the madness like lightning in a bottle, while handling deep themes of trauma and abuse with a surprisingly human touch. Worth a look for art and writing alone!

Gameplay-wise, Alice is a wonderful character to inhabit: her movement feels graceful and effortless, which is perfect for the platforming-heavy levels. Combat is more puzzle than battle: most enemies have a trick to defeating them, forcing you to think on your feet. Woven between these are interludes out of totally different genres: 2D side-scrollers, musical rhythm games, chessboard problems, and more. Best of all is a sequence in which you, growing to giant size, stomp your way through vast hordes of enemies. Some people might find the interruptions annoying, but I found them charming, and essential for breaking up the lengthy levels.

Which brings us to the few cons. The game's levels are long, and can sometimes overstay their welcome, so bring patience and a cozy blanket. Luckily, they're fairly easy (I played on Normal), but the final boss creates a jarring difficulty spike, which is all the more frustrating as he's perhaps the most despicable character I've seen in any work of fiction! Less subjective is EA's negligence: sometimes, Alice just doesn't want to run. I found that setting all the graphics options to low (then switching them back after a loading screen) solved it 99% of the time. Still, not great.

Bottom line, though: if you're up for a game of beautiful madness that tackles mature subjects with empathy, you could do a lot worse than Alice: Madness Returns!

143470842.review:
As a gamer who grew up with whimsical fantasies and captivating tales, Alice: Madness Returns brings a flood of nostalgic memories rushing back. Developed by Spicy Horse and published by Electronic Arts, this enchanting sequel to the classic Alice in Wonderland game delivers a delightful blend of childhood magic, engaging gameplay, and a compelling storyline.

Nostalgia Factor:
For those of us who cherished the original Alice in Wonderland game, Madness Returns is nothing short of a dream come true. The game takes players on an unforgettable journey through the imaginative and twisted realm of Wonderland, which is artfully reimagined with modern graphics while still retaining its charming and eccentric essence. Every step, every character, and every interaction will evoke a warm sense of nostalgia, making it a true treat for fans of the original.

Fun and Gameplay:
Alice: Madness Returns offers a captivating gameplay experience that seamlessly blends platforming, puzzle-solving, and combat elements. The controls are smooth and intuitive, allowing players to effortlessly traverse the beautifully crafted environments and confront the nightmarish creatures that lurk in the shadows. The platforming segments are well-designed, challenging players with clever puzzles and acrobatic sequences that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting throughout.

Storyline:
The game's narrative is a powerful continuation of Alice's story after the events of the original game. Delving into Alice's psyche and her struggles with trauma, it offers a more profound and darker tale than the typical fairy-tale retelling. The psychological aspect of the story adds depth to the already rich world of Wonderland, making it a captivating experience for players seeking a more mature and engaging storyline.

Graphics and Performance:
One of the standout features of Alice: Madness Returns is its smooth and seamless performance, boasting a buttery 60 frames per second (fps). The game's gorgeous and eerie art style, combined with the high frame rate, enhances the overall immersion and allows players to fully appreciate the stunning and imaginative world of Wonderland. The fluidity of the gameplay contributes to the enjoyment and responsiveness of combat and exploration, making it a visually pleasing experience.

Final Verdict:
Alice: Madness Returns manages to strike the perfect balance between nostalgia and innovation. It successfully captures the essence of the original Alice in Wonderland while introducing modern gameplay mechanics and an intriguing storyline. Its fun, engaging gameplay and impressive performance at 60fps create a highly satisfying experience for both long-time fans and newcomers alike.

If you seek a nostalgic trip down the rabbit hole, sprinkled with a touch of darkness and filled with wonder, Alice: Madness Returns is undoubtedly the game to play. Embark on this unforgettable adventure with Alice, and get ready to lose yourself in the madness of Wonderland once more.

Alice: Madness Returns is an enchanting third-person, single-player action-adventure platformer that takes you on a captivating journey. Set in the dark and haunting streets of Victorian London and the mesmerising yet eerie Wonderland, the game unravels the mysteries behind Alice's madness.

One of the standout aspects of the game is its enemy design. Each encounter is a visual delight, immersing players in a world of macabre and wonder. The boss battles are a true test of skill, providing both a challenge and a sense of satisfaction upon completion.

As a fan of the first Alice game, I was excited to dive back into this twisted world. The story line, characters, and atmosphere all meshed perfectly to create a captivating experience. However, I can't help but express my desire for a sequel. I wish the developers would consider bringing another Alice game to life, but I understand that is such a dream.

The only downside is the lack of achievements on Steam. Achievements often add an extra layer of motivation to explore and accomplish more in a game. It's a shame because they are available on other platforms.

143254351.review:
First off, big shame on EA for not approving the third installment for Alice. I've been following the updates on that for years and it was finally at a point where all it needed was EA to green light it, but they refused and won't give the rights to the creator American McGee.
I always wanted to play this game, especially after knowing the events that followed for Alice:Asylum (the third installment) and I enjoyed the story of the series. HOWEVER, be mindful on how buggy it is on PC/Steam (I heard it works fine on PS3). The blocking feature with the umbrella ONLY works if it is on default controls with keyboard. I had to do lots of research on it since mine refused to work at first, which unfortunately is a vital feature when dealing with the "cannon crabs" and the "menacing ruin" (i hated this one, I was stuck on a level for a long time since my weapons refused to work. One time the Vorpal blade was not appearing.) If you are using keyboard, for blocking you need to HOLD CAPS and then tap E and HOLD to block for the umbrella to work and have the projectiles bounce off to hit the enemy's shield. After figuring this out, I was able to proceed through the game fortunately.

BUGS/Glitches/Issues:
-Loading screen. This was my biggest issue aside from the umbrella blocking. When I opened the game, it would be stuck on loading for a long time. Unfortunately, it seems to be a common issue. I had to reset my pc multiple times and changes my resolution to the default setting. The other options i left on low or none/off. For me, I left alot of the options on default except the camera sensitivity and the interact button to "F" as a preference. Then it loaded for me after a few pc resets.

-Alice would randomly move forward on her own and it takes awhile to gain control again (I thought my W key was not working, so I tested it on another game and it worked perfectly). When this happened, I paused the game for awhile and she would reset in a way and stop running forward on her own.

-Umbrella blocking. Biggest struggle for me. Granted. I did not try it with controller and I heard it works okay with controller after I figured it out on keyboard. Unfortunately, you need to leave the umbrella blocking at its default or it would refuse to work.

-Jumping was a pain at first. You really need to time it right at times. It is not really easy to control but after awhile you get used to it. There is like a fickle limit on how much you can jump/glide. Sometime it would let you triple jump, sometimes it wont and only do two. If you do it too fast it cuts itself short and you would just fall.

-There is an autosave feature BUT if you are unlucky, you would have to start all the way over and listen to the same unskippable dialogue. When I was struggling with the blocking feature, I had to restart this area in the Mad Hatter, Mad Hare and mouse section SO MANY times all the way to the most inconvenient area and recollect the collectibles and teeth (if you die you may have to recollect stuff, sometimes it does keep it), plus redo all the switches to proceed. When I got to the part fighting the giant Executioner, I fell off and had to walk all the way back to the battle area. It was honestly funny seeing how big the guy is that you would normally not see during the battle.

-Also, there is no instructions for controls to move the puzzles (the picture puzzles). You have to move them with the space bar and select them with either WASD or arrow keys.

-The musical note parts were SO LAGGY. You gotta be patient and go slow.

TIPS:
-Use shrink alot if you are stuck or can't find where to go (there is also some pig snouts that needed shrink to locate them. I encountered it 2 or 3 times)

-Collect as much teeth as you can to level up your weapons, I did Vorpal blade first, then evenly did the other three. The teapot is SUPER helpful so level that as much as possible. All weapons were helpful in their own ways for specific battles and exploration.

Despite the bugs, it was very creative and enjoyable story. Good luck!

143192624.review: “Alice: Madness Returns” takes players on a surreal and haunting journey through a twisted Wonderland that is both mesmerizing and deeply disturbing. This sequel to the cult classic “American McGee’s Alice” is a dark and twisted masterpiece that successfully marries psychological horror with platforming and action elements. Visually, “Alice: Madness Returns” is a macabre work of art. The design of Wonderland is a nightmarish wonderland of grotesque beauty, filled with twisted landscapes, eerie characters, and a sense of foreboding around every corner. The game’s ability to seamlessly shift between the whimsical and the horrific is a testament to its artistic direction. The storyline is a psychological rollercoaster, delving into Alice’s troubled psyche as she attempts to unravel the mystery behind her family’s tragic past. It’s a tale of trauma, coping mechanisms, and the thin line between reality and madness. The narrative is both engaging and unsettling, drawing players deeper into Alice’s fractured world. Gameplay-wise, “Alice: Madness Returns” offers a blend of platforming, combat, and exploration. The platforming sections are cleverly designed, making use of Alice’s unique abilities and the ever-changing environment. Combat, while not the game’s strongest suit, still provides satisfying encounters with various grotesque creatures and offers a decent variety of weapons and upgrades. What truly shines in this game is its atmosphere and attention to detail. The haunting musical score, coupled with the eerie sound effects, enhances the sense of unease throughout the adventure. The game’s collectibles and hidden memories add depth to the narrative, encouraging players to delve deeper into Wonderland’s dark secrets. While “Alice: Madness Returns” has its share of quirks and occasional camera issues, it more than makes up for them with its unique and immersive experience. It’s a game that isn’t afraid to explore the darker aspects of the human psyche while delivering a compelling gameplay experience. In conclusion, “Alice: Madness Returns” is a mesmerizing descent into madness that successfully blends horror, platforming, and storytelling. It’s a game that lingers in your mind long after you’ve put the controller down, making it a must-play for those who appreciate games as an art form and are willing to explore the darker corners of Wonderland.

i wish steam let us leave mixed reviews because the game itself is good and i would ordinarily recommend it, but in my experience it's also filled with glitches that at several points ruined the fun for me.

first, it crashed a lot, most often when i first boot it up so i often had to boot it at least twice before it would finally load. thankfully it only crashed a few times in-game but it's still enough of a problem to be worth noting.

while performance was generally fine, there was a fair bit of lag in some parts, which is odd given i'm playing on a decent gaming laptop that should definitely be able to handle it. it was to the point where a couple sections were literally unplayable (specifically the rhythm parts which the game mercifully let me skip).

again, the game itself is pretty good overall and i'd love to recommend it, but sadly this port is so riddled with bugs that i'm honestly not sure i can unless they ever got fixed (and given both how old and largely forgotten it is by EA that's extremely doubtful).

142839343.review:
I wish there a mixed button on steam reviews!
Now, Alice Madness Return is a good game. Not an excellent one, mind you, but a good one. For starter, it has a fairly creative environment (although not really... queer. :)) and... that 's it.
The gameplay is... basic. There's no other word to describe it. Enemy design is... boring? uninspired? (although it does have some sense in the context of the story, they could have done something a lot better than this) a ''copy and paste'' a thousand times with little design changes for some areas of no relevance whatsoever. But, but, but... it does have some fun into it.
Same goes for the story, that could have been something if not for the horrible, horrible pace, predictable clichè and the guilt of using the victorian era's setting in an awful way. Still, manages to ''support'' the game by presenting interesting themes... if not for the atrocious presentation.
The soundtrack is not even worthy of being mention, being probably some royalty free music or something similar. Definetely, the WORST offender here.
And... well, it is time. Let's talk another reason (and my main disappointment) why this game is... decent, but nothing more. 
Being sequel of a creative, genuine, full of wonders and excellent ideas game such as American Mcgee's Alice is not easy.
Although both games were made by the same author, the difference in quality (in everything... but I won't write about the glory of the first one or I could be here the whole day) between the two is... monumentally profound.
But, almost as an unintended apology, this game did give it for free. But gods be damn, now the only reason why madness returns could be worth almost 20 euros is gone. they removed it (although I know it wasn't really their decision).
SO, after all my rantings, is the game worth it?
Well, it is playable, and for someone (I cannot believe the amount of people that found this sorry repetition of fights fun) even enjoyable and funny to play. So buying it (only discounted) it isn't something I'll tell you not to do. I mean, i did it. And in comparison to other platformers, it is enjoyable (after all, it was made by McGee, which is a really good developer).

OBRA MAESTRA TOTAL.
Plagado de simbología, la forma que tiene el juego para "explicar" el transfondo de lo que sufre Alicia es magistral.
"Eres como ellos, de ellos, creo, pero no ellos", esa frase me puso los pelos de punta.
No jugué al primero, pero bueno, lo voy a jugar cortesía del Capitán Jack Sparrow (guiño guiño) ya que no lo encontré a la venta en ninguna plataforma.
La historia es increíble, trata de una re-imaginación del cuento original de Alicia en el País de las Maravillas, con la ligera diferencia que esta Alicia está loca, o bueno, es lo que te quieren hacer creer.
Tiene un estilo muy Tim Burton, queda genial con el juego.
Les recomiendo jugar primero su precuela, "American McGee's Alice" que lo pueden conseguir en cualquier lado muy fácil.
Y si, tenemos otra razón para detestar a EA, cancelaron hace poco "Alice Asylum", que iba a ser la tercera entrega de esta maravillosa saga.
Ah, y si bien en Steam dice "compatibilidad parcial con control" en realidad tiene compatibilidad total, lo que pasa es que la interfaz dentro del juego no está adaptada para el uso de un joystick, pero el juego es 100% jugable con un joystick, y sin necesidad de configurarle nada extraño.

142629297.review:
A delightfully weird and dark take on Alice's story.

Highlights include: Satisfying combat (Special shoutout to the Vorpal blade), a gritty and mostly tactful story covering themes of mental illness and ptsd, mesmerizing visuals and locations with fantastic art direction and an overall wholly unique feel.

Drawbacks include: Mixed bag enemy design; with some being more frustrating than they ought to be, platforming (this may or may not be your "thing", it isn't mine but on the whole it's well implemented for what it is) and some pacing issues here and there.

Playing the first game in the series is not a necessary prerequisite for enjoying "Madness Returns". 

Overall I can't help but recommend this game. It's very creative and most of the time, a hell of a lot of fun. It's interspersed with some pacing issues due to gameplay and has some janky and dated elements, but not enough to ruin the experience. If the premise looks intriguing ... you should give it a try!

142624083.review: ES LA POYA TE ABSORBE BN CABRÓN

142616956.review:
Deserves all the right to be a cult classic. 
The Story is very well told and deals with heavy themes that are portrayed nicely. It was really well paced and had me hooked from start to finish. The characters are all so wonderful and feel distinct and unique from one another. It definitely gives the game that much more immersion to it. 
The multiple Settings of both Wonderland and London are presented really well. London is usually used as an indicator of what the next part in wonderland will be like and wonderland is just wonderful (pun intended). There is so much variety in these surroundings that prevent the game from going dull.
Visually it's just stunning. The Performance was iffy and that is due to this game having a poor port from the console. While it runs decently well it does play on 30 fps which could be a turn off for some. There was also this bug on the second chapter were loading into the level would just crash the game. The way i found getting around this was putting everything into default and resetting it when i got into the level. There was no glitches but a few crashes. Art Direction on the other hand is just unbelievable on how fantastic it is. Wonderland is just so well detailed and is really immersive. 
Sound and Audio are also great with the soundtrack feeling other worldly and the audio perfectly matching everything from the likes of attacks and movement. 
In terms of Gameplay, it does a lot and succeeds in pretty much all of it. The only complaint i would have about it would regard the lock on camera cause it can be a real pain trying to fight enemies while the camera of all things is pretty much fighting against you. Apart from that, movement feels great, combat is pretty well developed but I would have liked maybe more of an arsenal of weapons when going against enemies. The enemies are well diverse and offer a good challenge, the platforming is really good and the light puzzle solving is a nice switch up and is pretty fun as well. 
One thing I would like to bring up is how bad i feel for the creator of this and the previous title American McGee. For those who don't know, American wanted to make a third entry in the series called Alice Asylum and had spent 10-12 years creating a design bible of all the things he would have wanted to develop, however EA (of all companies) owns the IP for Alice and throughout those 10-12 years they just refused him to work on another title leading this series into a limbo and pushing American to quit game development all together. It really sucks cause this is such a fantastic game and there's no doubt that the previous entry was great as well and because of EA being well known for how money hungry they are, it has made one of the best minds of gaming quit on his creation and his career. 
Overall, Alice Madness Returns is a brilliant and twisted experience based off the Lewis Carroll book and while the performance was an unfortunate response from the era that this game was released, all other aspects really shine and is an experience i won't be forgetting anytime soon.

141724962.review:
Alice: Madness Returns is a really neat game, held back by the technological limitations of its time, and a propensity for making itself a pretty severe slog. Admittedly, I was playing on Nightmare, and it was my first run, so it could just be a skill issue, but I struggled to gain any feeling of satisfaction from a game that just feels like, at least on Nightmare difficulty, is trying to be as punishing as Dark Souls without having things as basic as its dodge functionality working smoothly. Target locking is an unfortunate place where this game's combat takes a pretty severe quality hit. Though some won't mind, I found it increasingly frustrating that I was being forced to use such a poorly implemented system. Locking doesn't actually focus the camera on your target, it's target swapping will sometimes choose to simply not swap targets because of the angle by which one enemy is blocked by another, which is really rough when there are ranged attacks that come with little warning apart from a small sound cue - lost in the mess of other sounds and music playing during combat - that hit you for half of your health. But that wouldn't be so much of an issue if it weren't a core fundamental necessity of the combat system. The aiming mechanics are very dated, so locking is basically your only half way decent option for aim, and on top of that there are certain mechanics as fundamental to combat as BLOCKING that you can't do unless you are currently locked on. This results in the combat feeling incredibly cumbersome as you are forced to engage with easily one of the worst aiming systems I have experienced since Golden Eye.
But all that wasn't enough to get me to stop playing this game, which I will admit was telling an interesting story, with a really stark depiction of Wonderland that I personally found really appealing. The environments are fun, even if the exploration through them sometimes feels a little basic, and the characters are all depicted in a very interesting, bleak style. No, that didn't do it. What did it was the bugs.
This game bugs out. A lot. Many times I would be beating my head against a particularly frustrating encounter only to finish it, see that there was one enemy kind of off on their own, realize they bugged out so now it won't fight me, but I also can't kill it, so I have to restart my last checkpoint - which were never remotely close to the place where you would fight, which meant you just have to platform your way back, grabbing several collectibles because the game doesn't record that you picked them up when you find them. rant over - and go through the fight all over again, sometimes having to bug test to figure out what would break a given enemy type so I could avoid breaking the fight. I want to battle big monsters, not the software. 
Everything kind of came to a head when I entered the third chapter of the game, and my game started to just look for any and every opportunity to crash and force me to do a hard shut down of my computer. So I said screw it and uninstalled, bringing me to you now.

If you have the patience of a saint and you can get it on a sale like summer sale (I am relieved I waited for a sale) then give this game a try, but it really isn't of a meaningful quality, so it doesn't really push much of an argument to keep you playing.

3/10. What I experienced I enjoyed, but not enough to deal with how poorly the games mechanics were handled while also battling performance issues and crashes. Buy it for $5, but preferably less.

141713918.review:
COMO HACER LA RECETA DEL POLLO ASADO AL HORNO FACIL

    Comenzamos pelando las patatas. Una vez peladas, las cortamos en rodajas finas, de no más de 1 centímetro de grosor. Después, las ponemos como base en una bandeja para horno. Pelamos también las cebollas y las cortamos en tiras finas. La ponemos sobre la patata y salpimentamos todo.
     A continuación ponemos los muslos encima de las patatas y la cebolla. Le añadimos a todo un vaso de agua y un chorrete de aceite de oliva. Así quedará mas jugoso mientras se hornea. Nos aseguramos que en el fondo de la fuente, haya siempre humedad. Así la guarnición no se va a quemar. Salpimentamos y añadimos un buen pellizco de tomillo seco a cada muslo (o al pollo completo, si has elegido la pieza completa)
    Metemos el pollo al horno a 220ºC si utilizas muslos. calor arriba y abajo. Dejamos hornear unos 30 minutos, hasta que se dore bien. Si utilizas un pollo entero, horneamos a 190ºC.
    Cuando esté bien dorado, sacamos la bandeja del horno, le damos la vuelta a las piezas. Así, se cocinará el otro lado.
    Inmediatamente después, volvemos a meter la bandeja dentro del horno. Finalmente dejamos cocinar aproximadamente el mismo tiempo, hasta que todo quede bien cocinado.

141642947.review:
Si Alice no hubiera sido una soñadora, toda la historia de su vida habría sido triste y se habría reducido a un drama banal. Calles sucias, gente tan fea por fuera como por dentro, lavado de cerebro, abuso de menores, prostitución, violencia, asesinatos... Pero afortunadamente, esto no es una película rusa, sino la creación de American McGee, que muchos reconocieron solo gracias a la primera parte del juego.

Aquellos que se oponen a las secuelas no deberían apresurarse a abandonar esta creación solo porque nació en segundo lugar y no puede evocar nostalgia físicamente. Tomemos la banda sonora como ejemplo. Cada melodía de "American McGee's Alice" contaba una historia por sí sola, incluso sin hacer referencia a los niveles. La secuencia de video del juego era solo una buena adición, porque la imagen que esta música pretendía transmitir ya se presentaba claramente en la mente. Sin embargo, en cuanto suena "Madness Returns", las nuevas melodías cobran sentido. Algunas evocan pruebas emocionales por las que tuvo que pasar la heroína, mientras que otras representan momentos o pensamientos específicos. La banda sonora en sí se ha vuelto poderosa solo ahora, pero durante el juego, su uso exitoso a menudo se nota con admiración.

Las armas parecen carecer de la inventiva anterior: son pocas y no son esos juguetes infantiles que solían fascinarnos con su uso inesperado. Sin embargo, no pasa nada. Hay armas cuerpo a cuerpo y a distancia, bombas de relojería e incluso un escudo. La técnica de combate se ha simplificado al máximo (al presionar "Bloq Mayús", puedes enfocarte en un enemigo y dispararle sin mirar, y todos los proyectiles darán en el blanco). Además, los movimientos de Alice son fascinantes y es gratificante simplemente admirar cómo "baila" alrededor de sus enemigos. A pesar de la frivolidad ideológica de un molinillo de pimienta o la cabeza de un unicornio en un palo, la magnitud del daño que causan es impresionante.

"American McGee's Alice" era sangriento, oscuro, impregnado de desesperación y único incluso en los instrumentos musicales que componen las melodías de la banda sonora. La secuela fue diferente a esta experiencia única desde los primeros minutos, por lo que no quería aceptarla. Al principio, solo la apariencia del juego despierta interés, pero lo hace con dignidad. Y luego entra en juego el contraste. La combinación de lo lindo, lo inquietante y lo desconcertante del juego atrae a una audiencia diversa que busca una u otra cosa. Algunos pueden sentir miedo cuando los lugares bonitos se convierten repentinamente en algo así, mientras que otros pueden sentirse incómodos al ver cómo lo terrible coexiste con lo amable y puro. Si hubiera existido esta pesadilla desde el principio, no habría tenido el mismo efecto, pero la pesadilla aquí literalmente absorbe lo bueno y lo puro.

Las imágenes mostradas en el juego son relevantes para muchos en nuestro tiempo, al menos para el público objetivo de Alice. Sospecho que se trata de personas cuya edad psicológica corresponde a la de los adolescentes: un sentido de su propia importancia les lleva a pensar que su alma es algo así como el País de las Maravillas, tejido a partir de sus propias imágenes y asociaciones del subconsciente. Inicialmente, este País de las Maravillas es hermoso y sorprendente, pero las experiencias que se tienen en el mundo real cambian su apariencia. Si algo terrible ocurre, el alma comienza a doler y convierte lo que alguna vez fue amable y dulce en una verdadera pesadilla de imágenes inquietantes. Cada persona que atraviesa un período difícil puede sentirse como Alicia. Sin embargo, no debemos olvidar que ella está loca, y su obsesión por las imágenes, no importa cuán tentadora sea, no tiene un valor real.

Si quieres apreciar la belleza y el encanto del juego, debes estar preparado para su contraparte, tan significativa como la primera, pero atractiva de su propia manera. "Alice: Madness Returns" es entretenimiento principalmente para la mente. Es fácil creer que ella es capaz de curar almas, si se entiende adecuadamente.

141404652.review:
I played through this game for the first time here on Steam, but I still do have the original copy of the PS3 version that I had played about halfway through a few years ago. While I would love to give this game a 10/10, I cannot here on Steam as this port has numerous and game-ruining issues - the biggest being that a major mechanic doesn't even work without editing the files.

The broken aforementioned mechanic is the ability to repel projectiles with the umbrella. Thankfully, there are several guides out there that provide as easy fix, but the fact that this is in a $20 USD port of a 2011 game is ridiculous. Another easily fixable issue would be the frame rate, which is for some reason capped at 30 by default. Again, this can be fixed with another simple tweak to the game's files. This port is just massively overpriced for the quality you get.

On a positive note, the actual game itself is fantastic... especially for a game published in 2011. Playing through it for the first time was a really unique experience that had me fully engaged. While I'm not usually into platformer-style games, the game kept me highly interested throughout with its storyline, art, music, and combat - all of which make this game, in my opinion, a masterpiece. This is now absolutely one of the favorite games of all time.

TL;DR: It's an amazing game, but only buy the game if you're comfortable editing the game's files for a better experience as this game's port is terrible quality.  I'd also recommend waiting for a sale, as $20 USD is a ridiculous amount to expect people to pay for what you get.
