I have been playing this game since 2017 and it never fails to disappoint me. I'm so amazed at the work, appreciations, devotion and pure passion that was put into making this game. I love the attention to detail all throughout wonderland. The symbolism within each of the characters especially with the main conflict in the plot. There are not many games that go into dark themes and even less that do it well and this game tells this dark story in such a unique way. I love the creative and unique vibrant designs throughout each chapter. It's truly a sight for sore eyes to behold these designs. I love the wide range in weaponry and option you get in combat to suit to your own personal way in fighting whether it be quick attacks or slow big bulk attacks.  Fighting in this game never feels boring or like any other game. This game truly captures 1800s dark elements and it is a game like no other. It has brought me core memories that i continue to cherish to this day. I love this game with every fiber in my being and it holds a special place in my heart and my middle school/high school years. Not many people know about this game and I recommend everyone to play this game. 

I'm ashamed and disappointed about EA's decision to withhold the IP from McGee to not allow a beautiful addition to this series and complete the trilogy. I respect McGee's decision to let go anything Alice related as it has only become a battle at this point. I applaud his YEARS worth of fighting tooth and nail to get EA to agree to make Alice: Asylum. I hate EA for bringing down not only McGee but so many other games/companies JUST because they want to be greedy or want to risk losing profits in a game they feel is going to not turn a profit despite the loyal community that it drives. Screw EA for the stupid decision they made in not letting this flourish with a third game. I give me best regards to McGee as well as the team that worked to make this game. Alice will always be held in a special place in my heart and soul and the core memories it gave me will continue to be cherish for as long as I live.

141243160.review:
EA’s MALICE: DISMAL PC PORT RETURNS  

To adjust this game to its highest quality, running at 60 fps and all DLCs, follow instructions here: https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Alice:_Madness_Returns

American McGee was one of the greatest and most underrated auteurs of gaming. His work with the original Alice all the way back in 2000 on PC was an artistic masterwork in atmosphere and game design, a complete, singular vision from an incredible mind. While gameplay wasn’t the best, it was still a great work of genius, a fully realized vision like no other video game. So in some miracle, EA and McGee released a continuation of such a classic with an even more ambitious title: Madness Returns.

The sequel was a beautiful, audacious game that expands the twisted Lewis Carroll allegory for trauma into a horror-heavy dark nightmare, making more deliberate shocking twists and visuals. It’s more playable than its predecessor but it isn’t as inspired. Its visuals are a mix of stunning to typical PS3/Xbox 360 resolution. It isn’t as crisp and concrete as 2000’s Alice. But besides that, it’s a solid sequel from a great game designer.

But the PC port…

Yeah, 2010s era EA games were not the best on PC. Titles from Harry Potter to FIFA were known to be locked at 30 fps and ran dismally due to poor optimization and lack of future-proofing. This was also the era of the physx software by Nvidia, which was utilized beautifully in Batman: Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, yet has a tendency to hinder performance. This has lessened with new updates and recent releases, but Alice II struggles with lag and  inconsistent framerate, even when the program files are adjusted properly. This can lead to many crashes, even some that require a complete restart of the game. It doesn’t make it unplayable but the fact that the original title is over 20 years old and suffers from less compatibility issues is astounding! And you know sure as hell EA won’t patch it! 

That’s the major problem with Alice: Madness Returns, the current condition of that game as it runs on Windows. EA put NO effort in making the game run smooth and consistently. And this is evident in the lack of future-proofing, making this unplayable without patches, which is unacceptable. 

However, you should definitely check this out! Don’t take this review as to dissuade you from Alice: Madness Returns. You have two options: patch it on PC, suffering through crashes or play it on Xbox Series X with backwards compatibility. I also highly encourage you to play the original American McGee’s Alice, which is available via Internet Archive or can be unlocked from the Madness Returns local files. 

In short, a good game but a bad port. 

Fuck EA

140701341.review:
[h1]A beautiful and chilling action platformer that is more than the sum of its parts.[/h1]
12 years after release, I finally decided to play this.  It holds up.

This is really not my "type" of game.  I think that jumping from platform to platform is the lowest form of entertainment, but the aesthetics and story here made it make sense, and made me excited to wander the inner landscape of fiction's most famous disturbed young woman.  Levels occasionally drag but are cleverly designed and fun, and I explored every area as thoroughly as I could to collect as many hidden memories as I could find.

There is plenty of combat in the game as well, though not so much that it gets tiresome.  A great variety of monsters are out there and you have four weapons to switch between to cope with armored enemies, fast-moving enemies, flying enemies, etc.  Combat here is at its best when multiple enemy types attack at once, forcing you to develop new strategies on the fly.

Some users complain about the lack of camera control during combat.  I found the camera angles increased the drama in a very appropriate way for the aesthetic, and the game is not so hard that you really need the most convenient Call of Duty controls.  I would definitely not want it changed.

Of course what really sell this game are the art and sound.  To be brief, environments are perfect - whimsical and intimidating at the same time, each of five chapters boasting its own distinct and dreamlike biome.  Characters are cartoonish yet ugly and disturbing, with unpleasant, muddy voice acting to match.  (Leave subtitles on.)  The childlike menace of the music dovetails seamlessly into the visuals.  Alice herself stands out against this twisted setting as graceful and poised, her voice strong and clear, her untidy hair tumbling about fetchingly through her exertions.

The story is not long or complex; it is instead slowly drip fed to the player over the course of the game through discovered memories, building to a satisfying (if not exactly joyful) conclusion.  In my opinion this sparse story is very good horror and I had strong emotional reactions along the way, particularly at the end.

It took me around 20 hours to complete the game!  I was surprised there was so much content.  To be honest, it overstayed its welcome a bit - again I am not "into" platforming so the increasing challenges of navigating the environment became something of a chore after a while.  But it's a journey I'm glad I made.  The environments are compelling, the combat is engaging, and above all the heroine is sympathetic.  I think you'll find it worth your time to help her discover the truths of her courage, her goodness, and her worth.

[i]Madness Returns[/i] is frequently on sale - wishlist it and very soon you can pick it up for $5 or less, which is an excellent value even a decade+ after the game's original release.

This game is an absolute masterpiece. I bought it originally when it came out back on the Xbox 360 and had the alice original port bundle as well. Was such a good experience on console. When I saw you can purchase it again I wanted to support American McGee by buying it again in hopes of Asylum. Unfortunately we are all left with a sour taste in our mouth.

140110716.review:
Game is great, but as anything that is decently old (10+years) the experience is anything but stellar.
Visuals are amazing (even if a bit low rez), the sound design too. Story is something to think about and the presentation is exceptional. Combat is good, platforming is better (in no small part due to quad jump).
So yeah, pretty easy recommend to anyone who thinks it's their jam... with one big caveat - you'll need to fix the game yourself.
As someone who grew up with games that needed a bunch of finagling with ini files and whatnot, it was almost nostalgic for me and didn't bother me much, but for anyone else - be ready for at least couple of hours worth of tweaking while following a guide, and later, game crashing/softlocking/hanging and then looking for ways to get past it (changing PhysX setting resolved a lot of them).
Over my run it crashed maybe 20 times, managed to crash my steam too once. Sometimes game just decides to not count a bunch of collected things when you miss your jump, and since game constantly locks the way back, you can easily loose collectables. On chapter 4, the chase sequences were impossible to do, so had to godmode it to progress...  If you're fine with things like that, then go ahead, game is good enough that this stuff did not detract much for me personally, but as they say, your mileage may wary...

140098385.review:
Sometimes you might think: Ohh how I would love to have the power of reading minds and see what’s inside of someone’s head! May I tell you, first of all that could lead to an infinite list about privacy settings and you might have to accept another annoying list of cookies before the aforementioned adventure! And maybe after entering another person’s mind you will learn the lesson to not want to attempt again or even come back more traumatized than you first were before trying to.

Let's get into juicy details! That's why you are here reading this, right?

I first played this game on xbox360 (Yeah I’m a dinosaur hidden for my own survival, you won’t want to see me roaring in a park, can assure you about it!) 
Is the second journey of Alice Liddell (but if you haven’t played "American McGee's Alice" this can be played independently) 
The game takes place in London in the late 19th century, where Alice, a bit more of a grown up, is still haunted by the traumatic events that took place in her childhood and she is now forced to reside in an orphanage under the care of Dr. Angus Bumby, a psychiatrist.
Alice, in a desperate need to escape her grim reality, retreats to Wonderland, the twisted and distorted land that lies within her imagination. There you will encounter various familiar characters from Lewis Carroll's "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking-Glass." These characters obviously have been transformed into distorted versions of themselves, reflecting Alice's disturbed mental state! Would you be brave enough to embark yourself in this twisted adventure to discover the rest of Alice’s story?

Overall the game is magnificent, even with all the years that passed since its release!
So many options to customize the character’s outfit (if you don’t like gothic Alice) also the weapons! The battles are really fun, the art is amazing and the scenery will have you taking screenshots and stopping in your tracks almost every two steps!

139914440.review:
Несподівано хороша гра із цікавим геймплеєм і шикарним артдизайном. Так, думаю, саме ці дві складові виконані в цьому проекті на найкращому рівні. Вони найбільше зачепили мене і підтримували інтерес впродовж усього проходження. 

Якщо геймплей можна охарактеризувати як просто достойний: він дійсно цікавий і під час моментів сутичок із ворогами, і під час платформінгу та загадок (хоча вони тут надзвичайно прості), то артдизайн же в цій грі на рівні шедеврального. Локації та персонажі надзвичайно різноманітні, унікальні. Я, мабуть, ніколи не бачив такого цікавого поєднання казкового милого сеттінгу із абсолютною психоделікою та м'ясом. Навдивовижу, все це працює в поєднанні один з одним просто чудово, я регулярно залипав на місці, просто розглядаючи місцеві пейзажі. Це все прекрасно доповнює музичний супровід, який чіпляє ще з головного меню. Отож загальна атмосфера справляє надзвичайно приємне і заворожуюче враження.

А тепер до мінусів. До них я би відніс доволі прямолінійний і передбачуваний основний сюжет і технічну реалізацію проекта. Останнє - це просто суцільний жах. Щоб змусити цю гру просто нормально працювати, доведеться попотіти. По-перше, що відразу рекомендую зробити - це залізти у файли з конфігурацією ігрового рушія і змінити максимальне значення фпс з 30 хоча б на 60, бо інакше насолоджуватися ігровим процесом просто неможливо. По-друге, гра регулярно вилітає, зависає на екранах завантаження локацій і багатьох інших місцях. Часто це пов'язано з певними налаштуваннями: у моєму випадку потрібно було підібрати оптимальне співвідношення розширення екрану, різних налаштувань графіки та обов'язково вимкнути повністю опції PhysX та 3D stereo. Варто зазначити, що це треба робити на етапі головного меню. Далі, якщо гра завантажиться, можна змінити розширення екрану. Якщо ж цих усіх кроків не зробити, ви просто зловите екран завантаження локації, який ніколи не закінчиться =). Підбір різних параметрів графіки і тд для того, щоб гра першочергово бодай завантажилася, у мене зайняв добрих годину-дві + надзвичайне горіння сраки. Варто зазначити, що це все всеодно не гарантує, що гра щоразу нормально завантажуватиметься, можливо, доведеться перезавантажувати її та рестартити комп декілька разів. 

Підсумовуючи, загалом мені дуже сподобалося. Сам факт того, що я пройшов цю гру, щоразу проходячи ці кола пекла, які я описав у недоліках технічної її частини, говорить про те, що цей продукт по праву гідний вашої уваги. Рекомендую, але за мої горіння з вильотів і вічних екранів завантажень даю 6.5 балів із 10

139838131.review: Completely unplayable for me. Keyboard control bindings simply do not work at all, and no progress is even saved. It seems that any time the game starts or loads, the keyboard bindings get set to empty. In the intro part of the game, mouse wheel seems to trigger the menu, which allows you to click through and see that the default bindings are all gone. Resetting them allows you to play through the intro, but as soon as Alice enters Wonderland, the bindings reset again and there's nothing you can do but alt+tab and kill the process to exit the game. Progress is also not saved, so you're back at the intro if you try again. I've found similar issues reported elsewhere online, but none of the suggestions work (running as admin doesn't work, antivirus has nothing to do with it, setting configs to read only, etc.)

139805821.review:
Co vám budu povídat, při hraní tohoto skvostu jsem taky celkem Madnessově Returnul..
Velmi specifická videohra, jak prostředím, artworkem, soundtrackem a celkovou filozofií a story-tellingem. Nic pro dnešního moderního hráče, velmi úzká komunita dokáže ocenit toto rozporuplné pokračování předchozího titulu z roku 2000. Gameplay je poněkud prúměrný, většina puzzles jsou po jisté době repetetivní, minihry jsou jakž takž dobré a kvalita kapitol kolísá od podlahy po strop. Objektivně hra stojí určitě za zkoušku, i přes pomalý a úmornější začátek mě ke konci začínala skutečně bavit. Celkově si myslím, že to co měla McGeeova Alice opravdu v merku byl skvělý vizuální počin s perfektním level designem a pokroucenými literárními postavami. Za mě 8/10

Edit: EA jsou bohužel idioti a tak se pokračování "Alice: Asylum" očividně nikdy nedočkáme. Nelze se ale divit, titul sotva dokázal splatit výdaje na vývoj a polopatě uspět, avšak fanouškovská základna je silná a určitě by to byl krok vpřed. Nedá se nic dělat, ovšem to co dělá EA poslední roky za patálie je na samostatnou smíšenou recenzi..

139768104.review:
Finally, I get to play this game on Steam.

I was kind of hesitant of purchasing it since it had a terrible controller compatibility with the official EA subscription, and due to the negative reviews regarding crashes and framerate issues:
So, to resume:

 The great points: 
- Compatibility with XBOX controller. (Thank you for solving the camera and the button mapping)
- Good resolution and low weight in comparison to other EA supported games.
- The excellent storyline we all know this game provides.
 -It's best to get the game on a sale ;3 

Downsides:
- You'll need to optimize the graphic card prior playing (also graphic configuration in game is recommended to avoid crashing) In some systems it's advisable to configure it without any high/medium quality graphics at all, just in case. There are also guides on Steam to solve that issue in particular.
- Some issues on the first launch attempt right after installation: 
I had to fix the  game files prior initalizing the game, also, some Steam controllers may get corrupted after the process. Better check out your files before playing and restart your PC to make sure everything runs fine, before asking for an unnecessary refund.(Thank you EA for the sh..ty installation issues, as always...f..k u)


8/10 for the issues. 10/10 for the actual gameplay. 
Happy Madness!!

139563888.review:
Una obra maestra, que a mi parecer merecería más que ser un juego de culto. Cumple con muchas expectativas, desde mecánicas más pulidas que su predecesor, como también la creación de mundos, la música, el guión, el personaje, los npc, la atmósfera.
Macgee lo consiguió. Consiguió reinterpretar e innovar en la fantasía de Carol, presentándonos un thriller gótico muy interesante, que hace una fuerte crítica a nuestro mundo moderno, como a nuestros miedos más profundos: el inconsciente. Nuestros propios demonios.
Me paro de pie por esta obra maestra que tantos años dejé ahí, pendiente pero acechante. Bien dicen que todo llega a su tiempo.
Por cierto, está de más que decir, pero EA debería replantearse más de dónde vino y hacia dónde va... ni hablar.

I must say that I believe that a lot of the positive reviews are coming either from nostalgia gamers or those pushing personal preferences. Objectively, the game is a 2.75/5.

139184661.review:
It's a decent platformer with action-adventure elements.  What I was not expecting is the amount of adult themes in the game, both in the narrative/dialogue and in the visual design. (copious amounts of gore)

Gameplay is fine, but is severely held back by the shoddy camera and the game's overall technical state. it's the absolute worst part of the game. Get ready to edit some config files.
* The game is locked to 30 FPS by default. Fixable by editing config files.
* The camera/mouse aim has a very bad smoothing applied to it. It is extremely inconsistent. Sometimes your aim will move normally, next second it's gonna be 1/20th of your set sensitivity for NO REASON. Or when your crosshair is near an enemy, it slows down even more. It makes aiming extremely difficult, and you are going to be doing a lot of that. I did not find a fix for this.
* There is a lock on system, but it also has a mind of its own, locking onto random enemies, changing lock when losing line of sight, etc.
* !!! There is a crash when first starting a new game or loading a save. It might be related to switching between multiple audio devices. An immediate second attempt doesn't crash.
* There are hit registration issues with one of the collectible types (Snouts that you gotta shoot multiple times). The hitbox on those is almost non existent and compounded by the aim/camera issues it makes trying to get these extremely unfun.

139067689.review:
It's very difficult to recommend this game, not because it isn't entertaining -- but because EA is actively trying to destroy it. Since the game has been on Steam, it's faced multiple [url=https://www.pcgamer.com/alice-madness-returns-has-been-taken-off-steam-again/]delistings[/url], and its simply not released in a condition that is playable. Issues include:

1. Terrible framerates
2. Unskippable cutscenes
3. Gating costumes/DLC in ways that are inaccessible, even if you are willing to pay for it

...etc, etc.

Compound that with the news that EA has killed the game's chances of getting a sequel by [url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/american-mcgees-alice-sequel-pitch-rejected-by-ea]denying its creator a chance to finish the story[/url] -- please understand that YOUR monetary support will only serve to line the pockets of overpaid engineers, developers, executives and generally unpleasant high-society types. 

Piracy is theft, and I'm generally not a fan of telling people to break the law. So with this in mind, I cannot (in good conscience) recommend buying this game. However, if you do decide to do so please consult the guide linked [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Alice:_Madness_Returns]here[/url].

[b]TL;DR -[/b] If you buy this game, you are encouraging the worst of EA's impulses.

Siempre lo quise jugar. Pero nunca me andaba (tal vez en parte fuese por los medios por los cuales adquiría el juego...) y ahora entiendo por qué. TREMENDOS GRAFICOSSSS!!! Literal, le renderizas un poco más el ambiente y las texturas de algunos enemigos y listo, juego de nueva generación. Muy buenos para ser de 2011. 
La jugabilidad está muy bien para el 2011, pero bueno se queda media cortina ahora. Eso de "enfrentarte" a jefes que en realidad no te terminas enfrentando per se.... Bastante choto eeeh. Pero bueno, dada la distancia temporal, no creo que pueda ser muy objetivo en este aspecto. Lo importante es que se disfruta y tiene variedad y muy vistosos los combates.
Padece de algunos bugs, como que queres avanzar pero como que hay una pared, pero despues al toque se sale y avanzas. O algunos enemigos de bugean (en especial los pejelagartos esos de hielo, podemos estar 5 minutos esperando a que salgan de abajo del hielo o que directamente se quedan ahi bugeados). Peor bueno, espera un parche como esperas el mensaje de tu ex diciendote que sos el amor de su vida y la mejor persona y que la tenes enorme (sí, nunca va a pasar bro... lo lamento).
Hasta ahora la historia me está gustado, interesante. Una lastima que la saga no va a tener culminación. Estaría bueno que el creador subiese la historia, si total a EA le chupa un pingo hacerla asi que... X. 

En fin, muy buen juego para recordar buenas epocas y si no lo jugaste nunca, como yo, además, esta buenisimo poder jugarlo y disfrutarlo. 

Pd: Muy buen Soundtrack amigo. El de la pantalla de incio esta GOOOODD.

138844918.review:
In all the years I've owned this game (and played on more than one occasion too, including a play-through over on my Youtube channel a few years back - link below), it only now occurs to me that I've never posted a review for it here on Steam.

Alice: Madness Returns is a brilliant 2011 3D platformer with a dark storyline. It's a sequel to American McGee's Alice, but even without playing the first game you can pick up the story of this one fairly easily. The characters are memorable, the gameplay is nice and smooth, there are plenty of secrets and collectables for you to find, enemies to fight with a small but decent variety of weapons, and sound design's great. But where this game stands out most of all is its visual design. Each stage you go to has a distinct aesthetic, and everything is quite gorgeous to behold.

The only minor (and I emphasise minor) gripe that some players may have is that one or two levels may drag a little. But other than that, there really wasn't anything that I felt particularly negative towards in this game. Definitely worth giving it a shot if you like 3D platformers and visually stunning levels!

As promised, for anyone wanting to see a sample of gameplay before buying, here's a link to my play-through on Youtube (be warned - this is from when I was playing on an older, non-gaming PC, so the gameplay's frame rate will sometimes chug a bit!):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MMFqe7GYvjM&list=PL05Yc3_TEBpM3PLj-tZULRLhJFaKrzzo7

138649272.review:
I want to like this game, I really do. American McGee's Alice was a wonderfully twisted take on the story and this one follows the same premise. But I just can't bring myself to review this game well. My major gripe is the safe function ie there is none. The game relies on check points, you can't save your progression as and when you need to. It's annoying enough when you have 2 directions and not sure which one to take, so you take one and boom, check point save and the path behind you becomes blocked so you can't go back and check. But it's worse at the many platform sections. If you mis-time a jump and fall to your doom you respawn at a check point and have to re-do the whole thing. Over. And over. And over. And don't get me started with the bugs; one bug I came across with a boss fight you have to use an umbrella. Except the bug prevents you from using it. So you have to quit (which you can't save so again, check point), edit the game and log back in.

IF there was a proper save function then yes, I would say this is a good game and worth playing. But if you're like me and like to explore, or if you're not good with platform sections, it's going to frustrate you beyond words.

138380349.review:
American Mcgee’s Alice and Alice Madness Returns will be one of my top favorites for being the most visually stunning games ever. Back then, I remember watching my sister play American Mcgee’s Alice demo in our old computer before because we couldn’t really afford to buy the game and although the controls and platforming were kinda clunky and difficult, it still had an allure to it I was really drawn to. I was so intrigued with Alice’s story, I kept going back to it and when finally I got my first laptop, I tried to play a pirated version of the game. Barely ran smoothly even at the most minimum settings, I still played it even though it lagged to an oblivion. Eventually, its sequel Alice Madness returns came. I remember seeing it in a game magazine and I wanted it so much but having no console to play it with nor a decent computer, I had to just to resort to watching Youtube let’s plays.

Now I finally got a decent laptop to play this game, when it went on sale I finally got it. Finished and spent hours on the game and although Alice Madness returns was pretty linear and had it’s own lapses for being too stretched out and repetitive, I still enjoyed it as an experience. Alice’s story is a compelling one. For her, Wonderland was her escapism and what represented her innocence. You play the game traversing Alice’s nightmarish world as a result of her trauma and see how her story unfolds. In the end, she eventually conquers and reconciles with all aspects of her trauma and fears.

The game has sure aged well and I loved how Mcgee had (emphasis on “had” because we won’t ever get another Alice game brought by the recent news.) introduced a twisted and surreal rendition of Alice in Wonderland. I love how you were thrown into the beginning of the first game as you try to regain what’s left of Alice’s wonderland in ruins.  

This will be one of the best games for me. As far I was distraught by the news that we won’t be seeing another game of alice again, maybe it’s for the good. If you want to play this game, just pirate it instead. 

Don’t support EA and its corporate a**.

138305362.review:
[b]Graphics and story[/b] 10/10

[i]Alice: Madness Returns[/i] is a 3D platform adventure game. The story begins in aftermath of tragic death of Alice's family in the arson attack. She is admitted to Rutledge Asylum, located in impoverished London. Dr. Angus Bumby allegedly helps her through hypnosis treatment to forget her memories. However, he begins to distort and twist the Wonderland. Soon she’ll follow the white cat into an alley. She meets an old woman there, invites her to her house and Alice suffers a mental collapse. That leads her to Wonderland. The smiling cat tells Alice that the homeland has changed, new rules reign, and a train has arrived. Our adventure begins by discovering the purposefulness of the train, retrieving the memories and facing the evils lurking, since by saving the land Alice will also be saved.

The story is extraordinary, tragic and petrifying. Apparently the game is based on the well-known novels of Lewis Carroll. It also took as a starting point the game [i]American McGee's Alice[/i]. Although this game is a more dingy, gloomy, dark and violent version that distances itself from the pleasant world of Disney production. The argument is quite simple and understandable. But we must put the pieces of memory together in the form of a puzzle to expose what really happened as well as discover the intention of the train. The language of the game reminds us of Carroll's poetic tone: he amalgams logic and poetry with unexpected puns. In addition, a psychological symbolism is presented at every moment. With this they achieve to perturb us in order to plunge ourselves in the traumas and in Alice's story. It’s a good adaptation that gradually persuades us of an oneiric journey in the sea of nightmares. 

About art is quite interesting. The game always contrasts the real world, the distortion of that world and the wonderland. Each chapter develops unique art, just like Alice's outfits. The game is fairly rich and harmonious in colour palettes with an exquisite mix of various shades. Art is also deeply influenced by various currents and artistic expressions: Victorian aesthetics, baroque, mannerism, realism and surrealism. Above all it reminds us of the paintings of Doré, Magritte, Arcimboldo, Metsys, Mark Ryden, Ceccoli, just to mention a few. The game's art design harmoniously complements the narrative, so we can comprehend the symbols, meanings, buried details, and plot clues as we get closer to Alice's thoughts. Each place reveals the character's personality before the depersonalization process. The design of each place is extremely amazing, that intrigue and capture our attention. It’s ambivalent: a protected maze; tidy and broken, colourful and opaque, vivid and sinister, alive and dead, fantastic and horrid; all in Schröndigerian overlay, that is, in paradoxes.

[b]Playability[/b] 10/10

The base mechanic of this game consists of the platform. The game is designed in the form of levels. Each of them contains a series of puzzles to open a path and thus continue. It's not just about jumping on every moving platform. It’s about discovery a way to cross to the other side. For that we have basic movements like jumping, leaping and floating. Those moves can be combined to reach far away platforms or take advantage in combat. It’s important to pay attention to the things on each scenario, because this game is intuitive through which it allows us to decipher the riddle.

Since Alice follows the narrative of the literature we know, she can shrink. With that ability, she can temporarily hide from enemies. Being small, she can go through small doors, see platforms or hidden paths, as well as look at notes on the blackboard. The latter through drawings tells us what we found in our path. They are purple indications. Hence exploration is important in the game. We’ll find memories, teeth (which are used to improve weapons), roses (which form for the character's health), and secret passages revealed through Pig Snouts' sneezes.

Each level is common, as sometimes it's just progress, while other times it will be fighting enemies to unlock doors, levers or switches. As we progress, the difficulty increases. Different enemies emerge. For this, we have weapons and outfits with dissimilar advantages. Each outfit and weapon is unlocked by playing a certain chapter. In combat mode, there is the option to activate concentration mode. This will allow us to evade enemy attacks such as counterattacking, for example, by rejecting an enemy's projectile with the umbrella. We can also use Clockwork Bomb to distract enemies, to open some doors or use as a counterweight on switches. It can be combined in many ways. When Alice is about to die, the hysteria mode will be activated. We can also improve our health bar through [i]Paint the Rose Red[/i]. Four shards are required to get a whole rose. The Radula Room will guide to the spots where these fragments will drop from completing challenges.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 10/10

The soundtrack was composed by Marshall Crutcher, Jason Tai, and Chris Vrenna. The theme of the score finds its substance in the dantesque world of Alice. The musical pieces epitomize how Wonderland is distorted and Alice will achieve everything possible to recover it and rescue herself. She’s her own protagonist and her own hero without the uneasiness or fuss of being rescued by someone else.

Now the music is polyphonic and polychromatic. It has a variety of tones, sounds, performed by various musical instruments and electronic effects, which craft a rich and exquisite concentrated content. Sometimes we hear sweet and cheery sounds, while other times we perceive sinister and gloomy melodies. The soundtrack attempts to maintain an equilibrium through the opposites: lucidity and madness, wonder and horror, light and dark. Everything is spinning between reality and surrealism.

To achieve their composition, the musicians use various electronic effects and musical instruments. On many occasions it’s based on dark ambient or orchestral arrangements. Some tunes contain a children's theme performed by music box melodies. But always highlighting musical pieces that contain violin and piano. That offers, through a sinister scale, the sensation of fear, horror and disturbance. It constantly accentuates the consternation caused by Alice's distorted world. In moments of battle, instead, the insistent energy of the percussions rules. But it’s soon mollified by the music on the scenario. Each chapter has a unique piece of music —we can listen to them as a looping. The musical pieces contain mystery and symbolism that make more noticeable the drama of the story and emphasizes the aura of each corner of Alice's mind.

[b]Duration[/b] 10/10

Like leafing through a book: always motivated to know what will happen. This game is an interesting artwork that comprehends psychological symbolism in an enthralling adventure. The game is quite long. It has several difficulties; it can be replayed via game+. The previous game, American McGee's Alice, has been included. The rest of the gameplay is worth living the adventure. In this way we discover different rhythms and gameplay, as well as puzzles in the form of mini-games. It’s worth finding out the mysteries of the human mind expressed in art and games.

[h1]Recommendation: 10/10[/h1]

Una historia que dejó huella desde su primer entrega con "American McGee's Alice", donde se detallan los acontecimientos que dejaron a Alice huérfana y bajo la custodia de un hospital psiquiátrico, en el cual es capaz de ingresar al mundo de las maravillas, "Alice Madness Returns" es una continuación que cronológicamente nos sitúa un par de años después de recibir el alta del hospital psiquiátrico, donde Alice se encuentra bajo el cuidado del orfanato Houndsditch, con el deseo de tener una vida normal, sin embargo, víctima de una profunda depresión y alucinaciones, se embarca en la búsqueda de los recuerdos que pueden conducirla a la verdad tras la muerte de sus padres.

The game has great visuals, atmosphere and an intruiging story but it unfortunately just isn't fun to play.

The game's combat primarily involves you button mashing until you kill all the enemies in the area before you're allowed to progress. There isn't a lot of complexity going on and it's way too easy because of it. Even if your health gets low, you have a special ability that makes you temporarily invincible and increases your damage, so the enemies feel more like a grind than a legit threat.

The game is also kind of a glitchy mess. There are instances when you are locked with a certain weapon and can't switch without restarting the game, or the menu mouse cursor remains on screen while you play. The glitches are severe enough to soft-lock you from the rest of the game. In my case it was the umbrella block tutorial section. I was stuck fighting an enemy that was invincible to any other attack and I couldn't do anything about it.

Also, it's owned by EA that would rather let this IP rot than let anybody else realize it's potential. Apparently the IP is too unprofitable but if anybody else gets hands on such unprofitable concept, suddendly it's a threat to their business... yeah, that's total bullshit.

Overall, this is still a pretty decent plat-former game, despite its age. The story line was intriguing, though, the dialogue in the 'sane' world was a bit eye-rolling. They were interesting moments that let you take a glimpse into Alice's reality and the depressing world she lived. It was an overall, enjoyable experience, though there were moments that made me uncomfortable in later chapters. The outfits of each chapter were extremely well designed and nicely thought out. Every time I saw a new outfit, I would go "I wanna cosplay that", which is always a good sign in my book.

However, one isn't able to fully understand the references of the scenes that you zoom on to. I could only make assumptions about what happened and figured they were references to the American Mcgee's Alice. I just am in the dark, because I never had the pleasure to play it. If that's the case, then that is definitely a delightful detail for players who've gotten to play both.

I would definitely recommend this to people, who like dark takes of classic tales and platforming games.

Un plataformero como pocos, incluso en pleno 2023, American Mcgee como diseñador de niveles y videojuegos nos sorprende con una mezcla poco usual para una época donde los AAA eran dominados por God of war o el naciente éxito de From Software: Dark Souls. Aún así la entrega de Steam no nos entregó, como en las versiones de consolas, el American Mcgee: Alice, elemento que debería ser primordial considerando que steam no lo tiene en catálogo y que recurrir al abandonware puede ser pernicioso. 

La historia del juego es concisa y gusta de jugar con los elementos de la Inglaterra de mediados del siglo XIX: donde la era industrial, La guerra del opio y la expansión del capitalismo deterioraron a la sociedad británica ,ello, incluyendo también a la psique de Alice y su aventura onírica donde las hipótesis del psicoanálisis y el abuso de poder del terapeuta generan algo más que una simple aventura plataformera: nos entregó una aventura psicológica donde Alice debe confrontar su culpa, los resultados de la falta de ética profesional del psiquiatra, así como una confrontación a los abusos recibidos por años a manos de todos los personajes que le rodearon. Maravilloso.

This game could be cool but it launches at a resolution that makes it unplayable on most modern monitors, where you can't even access the display settings in the game to change them to something that would work, because the display settings sit somewhere off screen. Very frustrating. Seems like such a simple thing to screw up too, because this isn't even a review of the game... because I cannot play it.

edit: Eventually got the game to run. There's a config file in `~/Documents/My Games/Alice Madness Returns/AliceGame/Config/AliceEngine.ini` and you have to search it for "Fullscreen=true", toggle that to false and then the game becomes playable. EA/Spicy Horse, fix your stuff my guy, like c'mon. This is _basic level_ stuff, just making sure the game actually launches right. There's dozens of forum posts about an issue that amounts to people not even being able to give your game an initial chance.

edit2: It stopped accepting settings changes at that path at some point. The game copied the settings into the AppData directory somewhere, I had to search for the file to find it, and it seems that settings file is now where I need to go. Strange. 137138981.review:
Un juegazo de plataformas y acción con una de las mejores ambientaciones que jamás he visto en un videojuego.

ALICE: Madness Returns nos narra una historia alternativa de la novela clásica Alice in Wonderland donde la protagonista sufre un trauma de por vida a causa de la muerte de varios familiares causada por un incendio y esto hace que el País de las Maravillas se corrompe hasta convertirse en una pesadilla infernal.

Es un juego de plataformas y acción parecido a los juegos de Zelda pero con un trayecto más lineal y centrado en el combate y la exploración.

El juego es un reboot de un juego del año 2000 llamado American McGee's ALICE. No es necesario jugar este para entender Madness Returns.



Hablando más en profundidad del juego:

Visualmente es increíble. Pese a ser del 2011 se ve de maravilla por su preciosa ambientación la cual es tan bonita que parece un cuadro hecho videojuego. Los escenarios son preciosos, cada lugar se siente único y diferente y tiene un significado narrativo dentro de la historia. 

Es un claro ejemplo que, para que un juego tenga buenos gráficos, no tiene que ser técnicamente perfecto, ni tener texturas ultra HD, resolución 4K, HDR, raytracing y remil paridas solo para poder ver hasta los pelos del culo sin dientes de sierra. Con tener a un buen equipo de artistas con mucho talento y darles libertad para expresar su creatividad, se logrará crear arte. 
Y este juego lo demuestra.



Por otra parte, tanto la exploración como el combate son excelentes.

El secreto está en las armas, que son pocas pero todas tienen su utilidad tanto para luchar como para descubrir los diferentes secretos ocultos y conseguir todos los coleccionables.

Además, se pueden mejorar para que sean más efectivas, lo que incita todavía más a querer luchar y explorar, ya que así se conseguirán dientes (la moneda del juego) para poder mejorar dichas armas.

Quizás lo único "malo" es que no hay penalización por morir.
Hubiera estado bien que hubiera algún tipo de castigo por morir, como en Bioshock Infinite que si te matan pierdes algunas monedas del juego e incluso otros juegos como Hollow Knight si mueres pierdes todas las monedas, aunque luego se pueden recuperar.
Lo digo además porque al final del juego consigues dientes de sobras para tener todas las armas mejoradas al 100% y ya no hay motivo para acumular dientes.



Por último, y no menos importante, he de decir que la historia me ha encantado.

El juego original American McGee's ALICE creó una historia muy buena sobre que hubiera pasado si Alice hubiese quedado traumada tras la muerte de sus padres y su hermana, sintiéndose culpable por ser la única superviviente. Y todo el juego transcurría en una versión pesadillesca del País de las Maravillas, dando como resultado una historia de autosuperación muy emocionante.

Este juego va incluso más allá y nos cuenta la historia a través de los ojos de Alice, tanto dentro como fuera del País de las Maravillas, donde conoceremos a más personajes y veremos como el País de las Maravillas pasa de ser un lugar verde y vivo a un infierno lleno de sufrimiento y tortura.

Es de los pocos juegos que he visto junto a Psychonauts y Celeste que saben reflejar muy bien lo que son las enfermedades mentales y lo que cuesta superarlas.









En resumen:

Un juegazo muy bueno y precioso desde todos los ángulos y perspectivas.


Cada salto es muy satisfactorio y cada parry muy gratificante y si lo combinamos con cada una de las armas cuerpo a cuerpo y a distancia que tienen tanta utilidad en el combate y la exploración, tenemos un juego de plataformas y acción excelente que te entra por los ojos por sus preciosos gráficos.

Lo único triste es ver que el creador original nunca podrá hacer su deseada tercera parte de esta saga (se iba a llamar ALICE Asylum) porque a Electronic Arts no le da la gana. Razón número 3904250348542895 para odiar a EA y considerar-la como la peor empresa de la historia de la humanidad por los siglos de los siglos, amén.


Gracias por su lectura.

137137776.review:
Apesar de ter sido lançado a mais de uma década, as artes e designs do jogo eternizaram sua beleza. Os cenários e personagens são muito bem feitos. Além disso, a Alice tem um cabelo muito dinâmico, que se movimenta de acordo com o movimento da Alice e do vento.

A gameplay é boa, mas fica meio cansativo depois das 10 horas. Os desenvolvedores sempre adiciona novos elementos na gameplay pra deixa-la menos massante, e conseguem, mas isso não é 100% efetivo.

A história é muito boa, e macabra. Muitos não sabem (eu não sabia até depois de terminar o jogo), mas esse jogo é uma continuação de outro jogo lançado muitos anos antes. Você consegue acompanhar a história sem jogar o primeiro jogo, mas precisa prestar atenção nos diálogos e principalmente nas animações (muito bem feitas) e memórias que encontrar (tente procura-las, vale a pena). Algo que pode te atrapalhar é o fato do jogo só ter legendas em inglês e eles usam palavras muito peculiares.

Outra coisa a se elogiar do jogo é a dublagem dos personagens, principalmente da Alice.

8/10

137117607.review:
Alice: Madness Returns! Prepárate para un viaje a través del mundo psicodélico y retorcido de Alice, donde nada es lo que parece y todo está al revés.

En este juego, encarna a la famosa Alicia del cuento, pero en una versión mucho más loca y demente. La historia comienza con Alice intentando recuperarse de la muerte de su familia y la locura que la ha perseguido desde entonces. Pero en lugar de recibir terapia, se encuentra en un mundo extraño y oscuro, lleno de criaturas deformes y peligrosas.

La mecánica del juego es bastante simple: tienes que explorar el mundo, encontrar objetos y resolver acertijos para avanzar en la historia. Pero lo que realmente hace que este juego sea divertido es su estética gótica y su enfoque en la locura y el surrealismo. Desde el momento en que comienzas a jugar, te sumerges en un mundo retorcido y colorido que parece sacado de un sueño febril.

La jugabilidad en sí es bastante sólida, aunque a veces puede ser un poco repetitiva. Pero la historia es lo que realmente hace que este juego valga la pena. Es una mezcla de cuentos de hadas clásicos y psicodrama oscuro, y realmente te mantiene en vilo.

En general, Alice: Madness Returns es un juego divertido y emocionante que te llevará a través de un mundo loco e imaginativo. Si te gustan los juegos con una estética gótica y un enfoque en la locura y el surrealismo, ¡este es el juego para ti! Y si no te gusta, bueno... siempre puedes seguir jugando a Candy Crush.

136887834.review:
Alice: Madness Returns, un juego secuela dirigido por American McGee, no aporta nada nuevo al plataformas típico, pero principalmente destaca por su ambientación, diseño y su apartado artístico, así como de su historia y personajes, ese toque oscuro y tétrico estilo Tim Burton es el que más llama y gusta. Es un juego que te gustará aunque no invite a rejugarlo. Si buscas un juego para disfrutar uno o dos días en tranquilidad deberías probarlo sobre todo por disfrutar de su mundo.

COSAS BUENAS:
-La historia es muy buena.
-La ambientación me tiene enamorado con ese país de las maravillas corrompido y devastado.
-Los Personajes y los enemigos.
-BSO.
-Buena duración, no es muy largo (10h).
-Los trajes de Alice son TOP.
-El ejecutor me gustó mucho, podrían haberlo aprovechado más, me recordó al perseguidor de DS2.
-Eh! Aparece el Gatete de Cheshire.

COSAS MALAS:
-No invita a rejugarlo (al menos pronto).
-Puzzles sencillos.
-Problemas de cámara y cambio de objetivo.
-Luchas muy repetitivas.
-Su optimización esta algo pocha.
-Solo hay un BOSS y es en el final del juego.

"Las apariencias, como muy bien sabes, pueden ser engañosas, Alice".

As a creative individual myself, my worst fear is losing the rights to my intellectual property as is what happened in this case, but unfortunately that is to be expected from a company as corrupt as EA. 136822867.review:
DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME.

I say this as a longtime fan of the franchise even if I have struggled to have an enjoyable playthrough on steam.

There's a good amount of reasons not to purchase this game, the largest one I will get into in a moment but first I would like to say this game has a large audio bug that renders all sound outside of cutscenes to not play at all, namely this happens when using bluetooth devices or a large amount of modern audio devices, there are fixes but are overly convoluted and do not work for every person so good luck testing them all.

Now the main reason to not purchase this game, fans will know this but for newcomers this is the second in a series of two games the first being American McGee's Alice which while not purchasable on steam this game can be modified to special edition in its game files, allowing you to play the first game through this one. These games were the entire career of a man named American McGee who has been the main developer and story writer of the franchise since its inception and release in 2000. There was a planned sequel to Alice Madness Returns that would continue the story known as Alice Asylum which was planned after Electronic Arts originally approached McGee about a sequel. As of not even a week ago at the time of writing this the project has been canceled after being reviewed EA felt that the much awaited sequel would not be published due to things such as popularity and other metrics.

The true reason not to buy this game lies in that, American McGee, the rightful owner and creator of this IP has been removed from it. After denying the creation of the third game which they originally approached him for they also refused to sell the IP to him so that he could publish his own game, thus entirely removing him from his own franchise he had worked on for the past 23 years, a franchise that from its very beginning was his and even named after him. The fact the modern game industry can take a man's own work that he has spent his entire career making deeply saddens me, the soul of the game comes from its creator not the soulless corporation extorting it for money.

That said please do not support this game going forward rather support Mysterious the company ran by McGee and his family if you wish to show any love for him or the franchise. For any long time fans or newcomers McGee has also released the Design Bible for what would have been Alice Asylum, so any looking for a continuation of the story should look to that and look to obtain the Alice franchise games through other means that do not support EA as this game and franchise is worth playing due to the soul it holds from American McGee which has been taken away now by EA. McGee has stated he will no longer be developing games whatsoever due to these events, and that any attempt at another game in the series will be done without his involvement as EA has taken his IP from him entirely. I will link below some places for more information and resources for any interested.

Official Post About The Cancellation
https://www.patreon.com/posts/end-of-adventure-81049672

Alice Asylum Design Bible
https://www.patreon.com/posts/alice-asylum-v1-78703655

McGee's Online Store Mysterious
https://mysterious.americanmcgee.com/

136782900.review:
Execution is too poor to be playable. 

First and foremost, the camera movement isn't constant. It's variable based on the distance of the terrain in front of the invisible pointer that the game, for some reason, uses to navigate the character of Alice. This means that a mouse turn might turn a quarter turn, or a full turn, based on what you're looking at. Get in close to a wall and your mouse SUPER spins. Pan across something at a distance and the mouse slows to a crawl. 

Maddening.

Secondly, the auto-save system is quite broken. If you die to platforming, no worries you restart close and can continue. If you die to monsters, YOU DONE F*****'d UP and the game will restart you at the beginning of the platform. So, so far back. Like maddeningly far back. Oh and the enemies are only at the end of the platform, obviously.

Thirdly, the key bindings! Whoever thought "In order to use your big don't kill me ability, you have to take your left hand off the keyboard and slam it over onto the 'enter' key"... Which obviously means you stop moving because you took your hand off the movement keys and die before you get it off.

At this point I've rage-quit the stupid game four days in a row and decided to come warn you all away. 

It SHOULD be fun, but the execution is just.. oof.

136757067.review:
I just found out about this game a little over a week ago... Normally I don't leave review until I have finished playing the game. But this game...

I haven't actually started playing it yet, even though it says 54 minutes on my account. I spent around the first 30 minutes tinkering to make the game support the Ultrawide 21:9 display and raising the fps from 30 to 60 fps; and then I spent another 20 minutes or so choosing the best Video Settings, Sound Settings as well as walking around in the game to get a general feel of it to see if it is worth playing or not.

All I can say it, the voice acting is absolutely brilliant!! And the random dialogues from the men aren't boring either. Graphics look awesome, especially from a game that was released 12 years ago. The bricks, the wall, very well made and the town is so lively. It even supports surround sounds, so I imagine when I start playing for real, I will be able to tell exactly which ways the enemies will be coming from just by hearing the directions of the sounds.

Now, for whatever strange reasons, EA didn't put up the first here on either Steam nor Origin. So I will have to watch the playthrough of the first game on Youtube, instead of being able to play them, before I can start to play this one for real, so that I will know how the stories are connected.

However, the main reason why I am leaving this review early on, instead of finishing the game first, it's because just about 10 minutes earlier, I was thinking if there might be a third game in development and due to release soon by any luck? Since this game is from such a long time ago.

So I found the news announcement that, (you've guessed it) that they canceled it just a week ago!

The article says something like EA didn't want to do it, but the Alice IP is important to EA so they don't want to sell it to American McGee. That was more than frustrating to read. Especially when I read more and found out Mr. McGee and the Team had already put in a huge amount of work in it, they even made a Design Bible detailing everything about the Third Game that you can download here:

https://www.patreon.com/posts/alice-asylum-v1-78703655

I really hope EA will change their mind about cancelling the Third game as the Creator really puts their hearts into this masterpiece.

Letting it go to waste would, indeed, be a shame.

At first my emotions regarding this game were mixed.

The game crashed 1-3 times whenever I tried to load a save file. 
The game froze like 2 times in total. 
At times the game felt older than it actually was, something felt off about the texture and empty space.
The pacing felt too slow,I feel like the game could have been shorter, some sections dragged out/repeated too much. 

Yet I kept playing for the little things. The outfits that changed every chapter, hair physics, creative gameplay, interesting plot that was slowly being uncovered, the music, the sections of the game that looked beautiful and unique. 

By the end of chapter 6 I was glad that I bought and played this game to the end. 
I also now share the disapointment of people regarding the cancellation of Alice Asylum. I would love to see a bit more modernised version of Alice.
Yet I feel satisfied with how the game ended.

I would reccomend this game to people that are looking for a platformer with puzzles, mini games, collectibles and fighting.

136516154.review:
[h1]TL;DR - Play for good platformer, not for good slasher.[/h1]
I completed the game on Nightmane difficulty. [i]Maybe for Alice: MR it's not a good idea[/i], here's why:

1. Dodges are atrocious. Enemies can transfer their aggro mid-attack to you and it feels absolutely frustrating. 
You can place decoy bunny-bomb which can get destroyed any second and you get punched for it.
2. Auto-aim camera is horrendous. It often moves to funny angles where you simply can't see you enemy.
3. Big enemies have a tendency to cast stupid grab attack. It's hard to dodge when you can't turn character where you want all the time while dodge-spamming. And dodge-spamming is the only way to dodge grab attack which is designed to catch you 100% of the time you're close enough even when mid-dodge.
4. Some enemier are too weak. Like they liteally just stand AFK. No joy in defeating those. And they exist even towards the end of the game somehow.

To everything else:
Platforming is beatiful. It's a pure joy to jump around and seek for keyholes and hidden objects. 
Game delivers that.
Level design is excellent. Every time Alice enters a new lvl she changes her outfit which is a neat little feature that adds to the environment. 
Arguable but you can feel how Alice moves deeper into her mind throughout the game. 
Closer to the end you get less story and more of some mad and unsettling levels.
Pig snouts have the worst hitboxes in gaming history.
Some enemier repeat thoughout the whole game.
Generally it feels like devs could use more time to polish some mechanics.

Sadly, can't say much about characters of Wonderland. 
It sure feels like their stories are underdeveloped. We don't get much sense even towards the end. 
That leaves me with some feeling of unsatisfaction. 

Overall - this game has it's charm and I'd recommend playing it for sure, even though it's been 12 years since it released. There are some minor bugs that I could address, but those are negligible.

It's a real shame EA killed the franchise, imagine this game with AAA graphics and modern technology. 
RIP Alice.

P.S. I strongly recommend playing this game with controller.

136432480.review:
Ten years ago, after a fire killed her family, Alice Liddell fought her way through a corrupt Wonderland in her mind. Now she’s trying to regain some semblance of a normal life only to have to fight her way through a corrupt Wonderland once again. Will Alice be victorious or will insanity overtake her?

Remember how the last game took place entirely in the corrupted Wonderland of Alice’s mind? This game changes things up a bit by showing some segments in London while slowly venturing into Wonderland. The first London segment has Alice getting medicine for Bumby from Pris Witless, a nurse from the Asylum who’s blackmailing Alice into doing free labor for her. This becomes the first segment into Wonderland where Alice has to go through an evil factory where the Dormouse and the March Hare literally work the dodo employees to death. Which is a clear reference to the deplorable nature of Victorian factories but can also work as a reference to the slave labor Alice has to do for Nurse Witless’s silence. The second London segment is about Alice narrowly avoiding a rape experience to see her former nanny turned prostitute, Nan Sharpe, only to get slapped by her pimp. This leads to the next chapter in Wonderland where Alice has to help Walrus and Carpenter put on a show not realizing that she helped them gather sentient ocean citizens for the Walrus to eat, including oysters and fish, until it’s too late. While it’s supposed to be a metaphor for pimping, I believe that there’s more to this level which I will go into later. In the third London segment, Alice visits her former attorney to get the stuffed rabbit he unlawfully took from her. The Asian art in his office inspires Alice to visit a country in Wonderland inspired by both Chinese and Japanese culture which is an inaccurate blend of both countries. This is justified since Alice has never been to either one in her life. During Alice’s journey to see the caterpillar, she comes across innocent peasant origami ants brutally attacked by samurai wasps. While this could be taken as a reference to the historical British colonization of the East during that time period, in the case of Alice, it represents how the weak get overtaken by the powerful which is how she feels throughout the game. At the same time, the ants see Alice as their savior, which reflects her desire to be the hero yet, no matter how many wasps she defeats, they just keep coming. This represents just how helpless she feels in a dangerous world. The very last Victorian segment is when Alice gets thrown in a jail cell after accusing the pimp who slapped her of burning down a pub/brothel. The jail cell turns into the dungeon of the Red Queen, who Alice thinks she must defeat once again to save Wonderland. However, despite the Red Queen’s actions, she’s not the true villain of the story. Just like how Alice believed that the pimp, while an awful man, was the true villain when the true villain was right in front of her eyes.

After that is the final part of the game, the Dollhouse. It’s unique in that there’s no Victorian segment. Instead, it begins with a flashback to the asylum, showing the torture and humiliation Alice went through. Then slowly goes to the Dollhouse, where the true enemy is revealed. The man I mentioned earlier, Dr. Bumby, who gives Alice and the children at Houndsditch therapy sessions so they can forget their traumas. Since forgetting is essentially a bad therapy practice all together, the true purpose was to erase their minds until they become a blank slate and then sell the blank slates to satisfy the twisted desires of the rich. It was not only Bumby’s plan for Alice, but he also wanted to erase her memory of the fire. Years ago, Bumby was obsessed with Alice’s sister, Lizzie, and snuck into their mansion late at night to rape and murder her. Then burned the mansion down to erase any evidence that he committed the crime. In Wonderland, Alice’s mind turns Bumby into a creature known as the dollmaker because, in the sickest way possible, he’s making dolls for the rich citizens of Victorian London to play with.

While all you do in London is walk around, you’re much more powerful in Wonderland. You can kill enemies with a knife, a pepper grinder, a hobby horse or a teapot. If that’s not enough, you can collect teeth to upgrade them to their most powerful level. You can jump and glide to where you need to go and shrink to not only find secret locations but see hidden platforms. Though the camera can get a little wonky to the point where you and the enemy you’re fighting completely disappear from the screen. For anyone buying the game here, be warned that there’s a serious coding problem. In the game, you pick up an umbrella which you can use to block while locked on to enemies but, when you push the button, the umbrella doesn’t even appear. Trust me when I say that this will get really irritating, especially with enemies where you need the umbrella to beat them. I had to google how to get around it and mess with the coding in the files just to use the umbrella and, since it’s an old game, I doubt Steam’s fixing this. You also have a time bomb which you’ll end up using more as a glorified paper weight than anything else. During the game, you can also collect bottles with artwork, shoot pig snouts to access different areas or get more teeth and collect memories so you can get the full story. Though I should warn you that the game isn’t open sandbox so, if you miss any, you’ll have to actually use the chapter select and start the game over right from that chapter. Which I’ve actually had to do a couple of times. This is why, if you’re going to have a collection side quest, you need to make the game an open world. So, if you miss something, you can always go back and get it.

Despite the many enemies you’ll find in this game, there are no boss battles whatsoever. Sure, the game teases boss battles throughout each chapter, like Chapter 1 teasing the Dormouse and the March Hare and Chapter 4 teasing the Executioner. Instead, both villains are easily taken care of in a cutscene. All right, that’s not entirely true. There’s one boss battle at the end of the game with the Dollmaker. Apparently, there’s a reason for this. American McGee felt that Boss Battles were becoming a cliché, so he chose not to have them. The only reason there’s a Boss Battle at the end was because he wanted to end the game on an epic note. Unfortunately, he failed to realize that Boss Battles are the point of battle games in general. You gather weapons, you practice your fighting skills to take on the big Boss at the end. Otherwise, what’s the point?

This game is addictive, yet disturbing. I give it 7 out of 10; stay away if you’re easily triggered but, otherwise, enjoy.

136423646.review:
Step into the twisted world of Wonderland with 'Alice: Madness Returns.' This game is a visually stunning journey filled with creepy creatures and mind-bending puzzles. It's like Tim Burton and Lewis Carroll had a lovechild and it turned out to be a video game.

The gameplay is a mix of platforming, combat, and exploration, but the real star of the show is the art style. Every inch of Wonderland is beautifully crafted, but don't let the pretty visuals fool you - this place is dark and twisted.

Alice is a strong and interesting character to follow, and her journey through Wonderland is both compelling and disturbing. The story tackles themes of mental illness and trauma in a unique and engaging way.

'Alice: Madness Returns' is a must-play for fans of horror and twisted fairy tales. Just don't be surprised if you find yourself checking under your bed for Cheshire Cats after playing.

136313963.review:
The quintessential goth girl returns in a sequel. Hope you like em Bri'ish.

Alice: Madness Returns is surprisingly hard to judge. A lot of the things the game does appear, on a surface level, to be really good - until the novelty wears off and the issues become more apparent. Inconsistent would be a good way to describe this game, but overall enjoyable and very unique in its own right.

The story is good - it takes the original children's book and puts it in a somewhat over-the-top perverted shell. Due to the inherent insanity of Wonderland this creates an almost natural blend. The game has a few very quotable lines.

The visual presentation is good - if not a little inconsistent. The animations are overall good. The cloth and hair physics make the game feel like a demonstration of whatever version of PhysX they were using at the time. The backdrop is inconsistent, ranging from good to very bland. The caricatures are great and create a Burton-esque vibe in combination with the morbidity of the topics involved.

Audio design is decent, but again pretty inconsistent. I can appreciate the decision to go for merely ambiance backdrops as opposed to musical compositions, but they're fairly bland. The SFX is really not bad. Love the sounds for the Pepper grinder (minigun).

Gameplay is, once again, good but inconsistent. When first introduced to it I was blown away with how seamlessly it blends ranged and melee combat while allowing for an incredible amount of expressiveness through only a few enemies. Almost all of them require a completely different approach to be dealt with. Unfortunately it doesn't do a very good job on expanding upon it as the game progresses and the jankiness starts to eventually claim it's toll. Many of the arenas are not designed for the sheer amount of threats thrown your way and the lock-on system simply isn't robust enough to mitigate this either. Enemies do not seem to attack by any rules other than some randomized internal timer - making it very common to just die in a single stroke of bad-luck (on Nightmare difficulty). The parry mechanic is very poorly implemented and way too limited. The melee weapons do combine, but very poorly. The "roll" (a dash) seems to have a will on its own when locked on to enemies. There are a lot of pieces here that would make for a great game, but they just don't really seem to fit together.

Level design is actually kind of disappointing. The game sets itself up for some really nice secrets through some of the introduced mechanics, but only uses them in the most blatantly obvious fashion possible. Perhaps I'm spoiled by Fromsoft games in this regard but all of Alice: Madness Returns'  map layouts felt very cookie-cutter-platformer. 

Alice: Madness Returns aged decently, especially since fidgeting with the config files allows for custom framerate caps. Unfortunately the game suffers from not being as coherent and refined as could have been. Worth playing even in 2023.

The game is a beautiful old gem.

It has an intriguing storyline, a multitude of weapons and combat mechanics, an eerie atmosphere, and is filled with dark sense of humor. 

The levels are all different and unique, although some of them can feel quite long, if someone decides to complete them fully (and as far as I know, collecting the bottles and memories doesn't give any award or achievement) but I do suggest to collect as many teeth as possible, otherwise it will take a longer time to upgrade the weapons. 

The only real downsides in my opinion revolve around bugs, just to list those that I commonly encountered: 
- The game freezing after collecting the second memory
- The game usually crashing when I start it
- After collecting the second weapon I couldn't equip the Vorpal Blade and I finished the level without it, to fix it I had to restart the game from Steam. 

Along with that the other downsides are just some specific parts of the gameplay itself. 

So overall....It's pretty good!

136045418.review:
[h1]Setting[/h1]
I have not played the first game. Therefore Alice: Madness Returns starts off in a somewhat strange situation. Yet the at the same time the protagonis can barely remember her past and I merely joined in on the amnesia. With regular switches between the dark, bleak reality and Alice's twisted wonderland, the story unravels on multiple levels. By the last two chapters I was more intrigued by the upcoming conclusion rather than the actual gameplay. A truely impressive feat for a game that consists of 95% gameplay. Without spoiling too much, the unique twisted wonderland with all of its disturbing imagery and the surrounding story make for an unforgettable setting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
While Alice is just a poor, insane girl without any skills but walking in real life, she turns into an instoppable killing machine equiped with a knife, a pepper-grinder machine-gun, a toy horse battle-hammer and a teapot mortar. Floating, multi-jumps, timebombs that also activate pressure plates and a shrinking ability to squeeze through hidden passage ways, Alice has all the tools she needs for any combat encounter or platforming puzzle.
The platforming puzzles themselves are mostly straight forward, but can be challenging at times. Yet I never got stuck for more than a few minutes. The tougher ones feel appropriately gratifying after completion.
Combat is theoretically engaging as every enemy has a way or two to expose weak points, but is otherwise reistant to most weapons. Yet the combat suffers from one major problem, which I will get back to in the next section: target locking.

While the basic gameplay is great, engaging and fun, the game is riddled with insanely bad design decisions. At every parting of ways, the player is left wondering. Is one of them a dead end containing collectibles? Are both ways alternatives to the same destination? Or is there only one way forward? Usually that would not be a problem in a game about exploration, yet levels are swarmed by points of no return. Every doorway, every jump can lock you out from going back without warning. Thus collecting everything without a guide is basically impossible, unless you want to rerun chapters multiple times.
These points of no return can also be triggered by gathering a quest item or killing enemies. This means that you have to explore every room with enemies attacking you, if you don't want the game to consider a room completed and literally teleport you out and close the door behind you. You might even see a collectible or hidden passage during the little cutscene that kicks you out.
Then again, once you give in to the madness that is this horrbile design choice, once you just don't care about collectibles anymore, every one you find becomes a nice little surprise, instead of others being missed opportunities. Maybe that's what the developers had in mind in the first place.

[h1]Camera[/h1]
That one is so bad, it deserves its own section. During most of the gameplay the player can control the camera and it works perfectly fine. But everytime the game takes control, things fall apart.
There are small sections where the camera jumps to a corner to display the whole room. Unfortunately the controls don't make that jump and still act like the camrea is following you. Once you push a button, though, the controls suddenly realize that they should behave diffently according to the camera position. This means you shuffle to the collectible like an idiot, running into walls headfirst. At least until you realize that you can simply swing your blade once to reset the controls.
Then there are "2D" sections. They control horribly throughout.
Last but not least, there is combat. Target lock is the worst I have ever seen. The camera merely tries to keep you and the locked enemy on screen, instead of looking over the shoulder at the enemy. This leads to so many awkward camera angles that it's unplayable. Switching the locked target is also a game of chance rather than a precise act, and locking on targets out of view simply does not happen. Everytime there are multiple enemies involved, you will find yourself attacked from out of sight by enemies with ranged attacks. You will have to unlock the target, move the camera manually and lock again. As a cherry on top, you can only block while locked on a target. The same button allows you to jump, meaning you cannot do that while locked on the target. Horrible design, plain and simple. Alice: Madness Returns shows its true horror with the worst camera handling I have encountered since Legacy of Kain: Defiance.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Mostly stable and smooth, but with occasional sutters and crashes. Completely unplayable with rythm puzzles, though. It's just a little 2d animation where you have to push buttons once the line hits them, but the processing is so unstable that I have simply skipped every single one of those puzzles after a few tries. The developers knew what horrible mess they were producing when they introduced that skip function.

[h1]Aesthetics[/h1]
God damn, is it beautiful. Yes, it is bizarre and unsettling and depressing, but the designs are so intriguing and unique, that you just can't take your eyes off. The age somewhat shows, but the art style easily makes up for it. Every chapter is a feast for the eyes and Alice gets a matching dress to go along with it.

[h1]Female Protagonist[/h1]
Speaking of dresses: I have to address this topic here. In our own sick and twisted reality where people seriously discuss how much of a natural hip sway caused by female anatomy is appropriate for a female protagonist like Aloy, Alice is a breath of fresh air - even though released 12 years ago. When she walks, jumps, twirls and floats, every move she makes is distinctly feminine. Butterflies accompany her in the air and when she dodges, she even blinks in a massive explosion of butterflies. The way she moves her hands while walking or positions her arms and legs when gliding are girly yet elegant. And so are the dresses. Every one has a sick little twist, but they are gorgeous nontheless. She even talks like a proper british lady - unless she goes into an eloquent rant. Alice is as feminine as protagonists get, yet she becomes a total badass in combat - and players root for her even more once she takes that badassness into reality for the ending.
I miss those days when female protagonists were actual girls with impressive skills and not just toxic men with boobs. Can we have more Alices in the future, please?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The game is great for the most part. The camera is jarring all the way to the final boss, but the other aspects of the game more than make up for it. If you're into surreal, disturbing imagery and goth girls, this is the game for you. Actually, unless you are a completionist who refuses to use guides and still wants to keep his sanity, this game is also for you. And it's currently for sale. Just get it.
