135869719.review:
Alice: Madness Returns is a captivating game that explores dark themes and motifs throughout the game play experience. The game's story is set in Victorian-era London, where Alice has been committed to a mental institution following the death of her family in a fire. As she navigates through the game's twisted and distorted version of reality, Alice confronts a range of characters and situations that reflect the trauma and abuse she has experienced in her life.

The game's unique art style and eerie atmosphere contribute to the overall feeling of unease and discomfort, creating an immersive and emotionally charged experience for the player. Throughout the game, Alice struggles with her sanity and the dark forces that threaten to overwhelm her. The game's story and themes are a commentary on mental health and the effects of trauma on the human psyche, as well as a reflection on the societal norms and expectations that can contribute to such experiences.

Despite its dark themes, Alice: Madness Returns is a game that offers a powerful and thought-provoking exploration of the human experience. It offers a unique blend of action, adventure, and puzzle-solving in a beautifully designed world. The game's focus on mental health and trauma is a welcome change from traditional gaming narratives, and its platforming elements offer a challenging and satisfying experience for players who are looking for something a little different. Overall, Alice: Madness Returns is a game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and gaming, and is well worth exploring for those who enjoy games that challenge their perceptions and expectations.

In addition to its dark themes and motifs, Alice: Madness Returns is also notable for its striking visuals and imaginative design. One of the most striking features of the game is the beautiful and unique outfits worn by the main character, Alice. These outfits range from a traditional blue and white pinafore dress to a more Gothic and macabre style that fits with the game's overall aesthetic. The attention to detail in the character design and outfit choices contributes to the overall immersive experience of the game.

The weapons in the game are also impressive, with a range of creative and imaginatively designed weapons to choose from. The Vorpal Blade, for example, is a weapon that Alice uses to slice through enemies, while the Pepper Grinder is a ranged weapon that shoots out pepper to stun enemies. The weapons are not only effective in combat but also fit well with the overall aesthetic of the game, contributing to the immersive experience.

Overall, Alice: Madness Returns is a game that offers a unique blend of storytelling, game play mechanics, and visuals that create a cohesive and memorable experience for players. The game's attention to detail in character design, outfit choices, and weapon design contribute to the immersive experience, while the focus on dark themes and mental health challenges players to think deeply about the human experience.

135853155.review:
Very poorly optimized port. Game has "console-itis" all over: the inclusion of arbitrary collectibles that have very little reward, weapon upgrades that have minimal impact, with an inverse curve making your starting weapon one of the last ones you'll actually want to upgrade (everything else is not only better but cheaper to upgrade). On top of that, a lot of the combat has this "zelda twilight princess" feel to it from how the camera focuses in, to how it functions in combat including how you can only use the block function during lock-on. Platforming itself it solid, for what little you get of it in bite-sized fragments. Devs felt the need to constantly break up the flow of gameplay by adding poorly controlling 2D side-scrolling segments, including a twisted form of mini-golf. Fortunately the game is so mind-numbingly easy even on the harder difficulty settings, that you can easily brute-force your way past any annoyances or obstacles. It's unfortunate that similar to these 2D sections, a lot of the 3D platforming is needlessly segmented and separated by constantly taking control away from the player to show off every single platform you've just activated. There's also this "shrink" mechanic that's required to see a lot of invisible platforms everywhere and access hidden tunnels. While neat on paper, this idea feels exhausting to manage constantly, as the effect of "invis sight" is extremely short-lived, meaning you need to constantly keep crouching over and over to keep the sight going for more than a half second. 
Some technical issues that also hold it back are how the targeting system rarely allows you to actually switch targets, including how you can't tell it which direction to pick - you just hit Tab and pray to the gods it picks the right target. Unlocking and re-locking is also a crapshoot. 
Finally for me, unlike the first game, there's no boss fights (until the very end) and there's tons of enemies that get re-used over and over and OVER AND OVER through all of the areas, which reduces some of the "unique-ness" of the zones (which is funny 'cuz w/out those "ruin" enemies there's still plenty of enemies available they could've used instead).
It's overall a giant wet-fart that was poorly ported. I'd say I'd give it an overall rating of 75/100. A solid "C" for: showcasing interesting ideas, but failing to execute those ideas in a strongly coherent manner, in a game style that requires technical coherence to succeed.

135775024.review:
I think this is more than just a regular game, this is an experiment that allows you to fit into the shoes of a crazy girlfriend's boyfriend - at one moment she is all so sweet and cute and goes to hug you, and after a minute she sticks a screwdriver in your eye, because she doesn’t like that you breathe loudly. But yes, even that she does is cute.
Judge for yourself, the game is the incarnation of Alice itself - first she shows you a beautiful Wonderland, and you're like "Wow, this is incredible." The controls are also responsive and airy, it's just a pleasure to play.
But soon you begin to realize that this is nothing more than a shell, under which a pack of bugs and strangely implemented mechanisms are hidden. 
A camera that works disgustingly in battles - you are welcome. A bugging five (FIVE) times in a row teapot that has become impossible to stun - not a problem, this is just a beginning. Rolling back half a level after dying in the arena - thank you, come again.
But this is a positive feedback after all, so a few words about the successful parts of the game:
[list]
    [*]Alice herself. Seriously, her design and animations, her weapons and different skins are just perfect
    [*]Story. The plot of the game is far from the literary original, but it still retains its main distinguishing features - a dark story about an altered consciousness disguised as a beautiful children's (or not so) fairy tale.
    [*]Cheshire cat. I mean, gothic kitty with a voice of a killer and a sense of humor like Salem from [i]Sabrina the Teenage Witch[/i], what else do you need?
[/list]

Now I have a crush on crazy black-haired gothic girls with knives.

Alice Madness Returns es un juegazo Hack&Slash con plataformeo que aprovecha el lore acumulado en el inconsciente colectivo sobre el País de las Maravillas para llevarte de la mano a una introspección sobre la locura, el abuso, lo visceral y lo grotesco.

Lo bueno:

- El sistema de combate está muy bien mimetizado con la variedad de enemigos. Los diferentes retos mecánicos que suponen la introducción en un combate de enemigos diferentes es especialmente divertida.
- La ambientación y el estilo artístico es una pasada. Estas deseando siempre avanzar en la historia para ver cómo van a interpretar los autores el siguiente pasaje del País de las Maravillas. 
- Buena historia. No es una obra de arte, pero es muy potente. Para los buenos observadores, cargada de simbolismos dentro del juego.


Lo malo:

- El plataformeo es repetitivo y lleno de errores. Se hace muy frustrante como, en muchas ocasiones, las hitboxes no acompasan a los saltos a la hora de acceder a una plataforma. Los respiraderos que elevan a Alice en el aire también dan muchos errores. 
- El sistema de logros no está implementado en Steam. Es muy duro, porque precisamente este juego da para logros muy curiosos y divertidos. Todo una decepción si eres un completista.

Alice: Madness Returns is simply an amazing fucking game.

The atmosphere, the storyline, characters, enemies, mechanics you name it this game brings it although that may just be a "me" vibe I truly love this game. What seemed kinda funny to me was from the very beginning you think "Gee, Alice is such a sweet innocent little girl, why does she end up going through such hellish things?" Well, if my memories were fractured/lost I would probably be going through my own crisis of hell too trying to piece everything back together also if I had to murder a few "things" along the way then yes I would you're damn right I would and I'd do it unforgivably too. On the other hand let's toss it up to saying Alice is just on some serious drugs and this "Wonderland" she keeps going to is just her tripping real hard on whatever drugs she is taking but what about the killing right? Yeah well drugs man, she could've been hallucinating so badly that murdering a little here or there was all just part of this sick/twisted plot I made up but it'd be one hell of a plot right?!

Alice's reality is already twisted enough though even before you start thinking up stupid plots like I did. Alice is just struggling to fix what is broken what is crumbling. Again if I was in this sweet innocent girl's shoes I'd stop at nothing to take back/remember the more peaceful memories I treasured so if it means going a little mad then let it be so. All in all I'm just in completely in love and addicted to playing. Alice's character design/outfits/abilities or weapons as well are just really cool. I still think she's a good example of Wednesday Addams.

Anyway 1000/10 a great game. I'd go absolutely mad with Alice any day or any time but that cat? Yeah fuck that cat.

134921195.review:
Right so after being lazy for so long I finally get to write this review for both games.

TLDR IMHO American Mcgee's Alice > Madness Returns

Let's begin the first game. The movement and the fact that the entire game was created using a modified Quake 3 engine gave me conflicting feelings when I first started playing it. I thought the hitboxes would be a major issue, and they were, but not to the extent I had anticipated. The developers found a very simple fix for this: absolutely everything you kill now grants you both Sanity and Will (HP and Mana), ensuring that you never run out of either resource.

PLATFORMING: The platforming is quite ok, nothing to write home about, but it did the job and at times it was even entertaining, if it weren't for the screaming enemies who would sometimes launch you into Narnia because of either FPS or even maybe intentional, pushing  Alice to her death most of the time. One aspect of Alice's platforming that I didn't enjoy was how light she seemed, and I thought her boots were occasionally smeared with grease, which prevented her from stopping right away.

WORLD DESIGN: With level design that occasionally makes you feel like you're on LSD, to capturing being left in a mental asylum, to reasonably cheerful locations, to a true warzone, and so on and so forth, the developers were able to successfully transport you inside Alice's damaged mind.
The player is presented and told the levels' stories in a very effective manner. My favorite section was the chess levels, where there were several gimmicks to passing the levels, sort of like playing chess, but not really.
The horrible water level appeared just as I was ready to thank Jesus that there is no water level in this game. It wasn't all that bad, but it could have been better.
You eventually arrive at what I would personally refer to as Hell after navigating vortexes, libraries, castles, and vulcanic regions during the course of the game. The Queen of Hearts levels were fantastic, and you felt pretty uncomfortable in the region because it was literally made of meat and bodies; the sound Alice was making as she stepped on grass, wood, or stone had been replaced by a mushy sound.


COMBAT is one area in which I eagerly anticipated starting Madness Returns in order to play a game with better combat, only to return dissapointed to the original title.
In contrast to Madness Returns, melee fighting in this game is not recommended, and using all of your available weapons is usually the best course of action. You must throw your knife if you lack Will(Mana), but it has a reasonable share of CD.
With the ability to combine them into lethal combos, the 10 weapons you unlock as you advance through the game are immensely entertaining to use.
The fact that practically every weapon in the game has a different fire mode that performs something else is something I really liked.

ENEMIES, GORE, BOSSES: I was shocked that all three of these aspects of the second game were subpar. This game features a wide array of enemies, including Pawns, Grasshoppers, Ladybugs, Mushrooms, and Demons in addition to the standard Card Guards.
I wasn't expecting to be able to cut Card Guards in half in addition to seeing their heads decapitated and running around like chickens with blood pouring from their necks. [spoiler] The decapitation of the Cheshire cat was also very unexpected and made me feel bad for him, but in the end, everybody that dies comes back, as we see at the end and in the next game. [/spoiler]
In this game, there are 7 bosses, and each of them plays very differently from the others, encouraging you to use all of your weapons and identify their weaknesses in order to defeat them more quickly and easily. Some of the bosses are immune to damage and must be defeated by shooting them in vulnerable areas, so you must be somewhat strategic. The final battle with the Jabberwock was the most frustrating because for some reason—again, possibly connected to FPS or I dunno, would start spamming the flame attack, killing Alice right away.
I have yet in this lifetime to play another game where you kill somebody by making them sneeze so hard their head explodes so that was a huge plus from me.


THE SOUNDTRACK: Far superior to Madness Returns, I remember almost all of the OST, being very different based on the area you are in, some of it really capturing the feeling of mental ilness and Alice going mad.[spoiler] For instance in the battle with the Dutchess you can hear a woman screaming [/spoiler]. In contrast I can't remember anything from Madness Returns exept the combat music as it felt super generic and repetitive and that was a major dissapointment.

MADNESS RETURNS:

PLATFORMING: The ability to triple jump, dash, glide, and generally have greater control over Alice made it significantly superior to the first game. There was also no longer any grease on her boots. Yet in my opinion, the more unique platforming ideas were dropped in favor of simpler, safer areas. But, the game now has secret locations that you can reach using new gameplay mechanisms that are exciting and enjoyable to use.
This was a significant extra addition that I appreciated, giving the platforming more incentive to experiment where you can go while trying your triple jump and dash range. The game introduced collectibles, which for me were like a drug and I had to find them all. These collectibles were intriguing not just for their own sake but also because each one contained a tiny piece of information or dialogue that added to our understanding of Alice and the perspectives that others have of her.

WORLD DESIGN: Regarding world design, I genuinely feel conflicted. If American Mcgee or the crew is reading this, please know that you have my utmost respect for creating an underwater level—not really underwater, but I'll count it—that I actually loved playing and might even consider one of the game's best locations.
Now, as I've already mentioned, some regions I love and others I detest to the point of being boring and dull. My expectations for the remainder of the game were raised by the initial area where the transformation takes place. The Japanese area, also known as "The Oriental Grove," was the area that I disliked the most and wished it had ended sooner. But like  Jesus himself Chapter 4 and the Queensland came and my interest and desire to continue playing after that awful zone came back. 

COMBAT: Darksouls, I will skip this part because I want to talk about the bosses and the steam review has a limit. All I will say is that the combat is generic and we only have 4 weapons this time, not that many combinations this time. :(

BOSSES: Again. What the hell happened here????I have never in my life felt so cockblocked by a game. Just when you are about to fight a "Boss" they die or you don't fight them at all........why???The rabbit and the mouse that escaped their prison in the first game now own Hatter's factory and get crushed by him in one second....huh?The other boss from the Underwater level, whose name I can't remember or what his plot was (again showing how underwhelming this section of the game is), gets killed just when you were ready to fight him.The one that literally made me laugh was the Executioner. I was happy that we could literally hit him and fight him, but he is invincible, and you have to run from him.[spoiler]Then Alice finds a cake that says "Eat me", literally eats a piece, grows 5x the size of my homie, and with a smug face, crushes him under her boot........ =)))))))))) ) [/spoiler]Also, all the bosses that you had to fight in the first game are now .... your friends and help you???? Like, homie, you killed them before, why did they just agree to help you? It's not like they don't remember. They all remember what you did to them.The final boss was fun, sure, but this game has only 1 BOSS, the first game had 7
Would I still recommend the 2nd game? Yes it's good, but the first one is better. (Imo)

134314520.review:
I think one of the first things to say about this game is that it is unfinished, there were so many ideas left on the floor that it is crazy. The official art book for the game delves into a lot of the cut content. It sounds like what happened is EA pulled a classic EA move and simply demanded the game be done ahead of schedule, resulting in the developers having to hurriedly slam together the pieces they already had finished. 

That having all been said I love this game - it's in my top 20 of all time. It's so imaginative and dark and creepy and unique but in a way that doesn't rely on gore or language (though the game has plenty of gore if that's what you're after). The game itself is a linear third person action game with platforming and combat being the main aspects, with a dash of some puzzle solving. Today in 2023 it's an basically dead style of game, they hardly make these anymore. Everything here works and works well - combat is fast and brutal and has just enough variety to stay fresh, the platforming is tight and fun and Alice controls lovely, and the puzzles are quick and snappy and just enough satisfying without being annoying. 

The real star here is the music, the environments, etc. This game is an absolute mood, man. The level at the bottom of the ocean and the queens castle in particular are just absolute dreamscapes, or perhaps nightmarescapes, but they are just so lovely and memorable. For the era this game had some really slick graphics, especially Alice's hair which behaves exactly as you would expect it to. The music is absolutely awesome - creepy drawn out notes and bellows that underscore the environment, and one of the best combat themes in a game ever (seriously it's amazing, an adrenaline injection for every battle, and it has a few epic mixup variations sometimes too).

The game isn't perfect however, far from it. The last few levels, especially the final one, really just go on way too long and seem to be artificially extending their size in cheap ways to pad the game length - this being a result of the development not being truly finished. While the combat has good variety, over the length of the game (and it's a decently lengthy game for its type) it can start to wear a tad thin by the end. The developers highlight a few weapons, enemies, and moves that were forcibly left on the cutting room floor in the art book; the game was also intended to just have more in general, more areas, bosses, puzzle elements, etc. For being a cobbled together game though they really did a good job and it shows, but it's too bad to see that corporate shenanigans stood in the way of a finished product that would have been even better than this already great game.

The story is good but also vague and heavy on the allegory and metaphors, which I suppose you would expect nothing less from the mind-travels of an adult Alice. Nothing here will shock you or blow your mind, but it's a good story that services the game well. 

If the game looks visually interesting to you, buy it, you'll love it regardless of whether the gameplay appeals to you. If however this particular visual style doesn't appeal to you, it comes down to whether games of this type and era appealed to you back in their time. If you like third person action combat platformers this is a super solid one. If you didn't really enjoy this type of game back then though this game doesn't do anything so exceptionally above and beyond gameplay wise that it'll change your mind. Me? I've beaten it three times, once on PS3 and twice on PC. It's a damn good game.

134230079.review:
American Mcgee's Alice: is a personal 10/10
I have to finish Alice: Madness Returns before giving a verdict!
I've always wanted to play the first game (American Mcgee's Alice) and the sequel, And now that I have, This game is a easy recommendation! I also was able to play the first game through steam. To play the first game, you must download a windows 10/11 fix for the game which you can find online (this is because the first game was locked DLC for the 2nd game you can't acquire anymore)! All you have to do is fix the in games files to play the first game, under documents, my games, and you will see a file "Alice:Madness returns (from there, you will see the file AliceGame, click on that and then click the config file). Once you do that you will see the Alice Engine.ini! 

Edit it with notepad,replace the entire [AliceGame.AliceGameEngine] seection with these lines:

[AliceGame.AliceGameEngine]

Alice1Path=..\..\Alice1\bin
GIsSpecialPCEdition=TRUE

The first game is easily the most unique game I've played, having a darker twist on one of my favorite stories growing up! Once you're able to run this game, it is masterfull I promise! 

For the second game, make sure make sure you fix the games Defaultengine.ini to make the game run at 60 FPS, once you do this game is fantastic! 

in the  Defaultengine.ini make sure to fix the values!
MinSmoothedFrameRate=22
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=31
and change one of these values to: 
MinSmoothedFrameRate=22
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=60

(Also make sure to put GIsSpecialPCEdition=TRUE 
on the Defaultengine.ini as well)

134054206.review:
[h3]Alice: Madness Returns[/h3]

is a really interesting take on the *Alice in Wonderland* World, where Players are not just exploring the wonders of a very weirdly mysterious Environment, but also the deep and unexpected psyche of the Protagonist Alice herself. And how unexpected some of the Plots are.
Fighting foes, solving Puzzles and uncovering the Truth that is hidden behind a dark Web woven by Traumata during her childhood, Players have to help Alice to finish her journey.

And how simple as it is, the more enjoyable it can get, with its easy to learn controls and a simple Combat-System to fight a lot of Enemies and even some Bosses. Also the Levels have a nice touch to the Environmental Themes and Alice’s Clothes change with it.
There are also many interesting Characters inside the Game, some old ones and some new ones Alice is able to talk to and hear their Story of what has happened to them while she was gone and also what has happened to herself in that Time since her last Adventure in the Wonderland.

The Game’s strength is definitely is definitely its Atmosphere and the Art style it uses to establish the Themes of the different Locations the Player has to go through and all the Puzzles and Quests to solve to unlock the Gates to the next Locations.
Also the Combat is nicely implemented in this Game and not to difficult to handle, allows to getting immersed in this fantastic and weirdly freaky looking World and to fall into *Madness* alongside Alice herself.

But there are also some weak points to mention for this Game. The Graphics in the Texture and 3D-Model departement lack a lot of Details and Quality and could need a little bit of overhaul to support the Artistic Style much better.

I recommend this Game to Players who like simple 3D Plattformer sprinkled with simple action Combat and also for those who want to see Alice’s real View of the Wonderland.
---------------------------------
[h3]Points i give this Game (average Points 7,41 / 10):[/h3]
5,2 / 10 Graphic (Old graphhic, would need a little bit improvement)
8 / 10 Art-Style (Well designed World-Build that really support the Themes of the Locations)
9,2 / 10 Atmosphere (Perfect Atmosphere of Madness and depression the Hero-Character has to feel and so the Player too)
6,8 / 10 Gameplay (Easy to learn Gameplay. Plattformer, Puzzles and Combat with Bossfights too)
9,5 / 10 Story (The Story really had some surprising and disturbing Plots. Would like to see the Prequel coming to Steam and a Sequel to continue the Story)
7 / 10 Characters (Lots of Characters known from different Versions of Alice in Wonderland Stories and some new ones too. Nice interactions with them, would have liked to see more of them.)
6,2 / 10 Soundtrack (Soundtracks fit the Environment. The Combat-Sound tho is a little bit to repetitive)

This port of the game is a buggy mess so Googling the necessary fixes will be important for your enjoyment. (60fps unlock, some keybinds if you REALLY want to play with keyboard and mouse etc.)

That being said, this game is amazing. The artistic direction, level layout, writing, character models and enemy variety are all masterful, accompanied by an appropriately eerie soundtrack and amazing ambience, this game is an absolute treat to play. Alice controls tightly and the collectible and *light* RPG elements give the game a breath of fresh air.

My only main issue with this game is the lack of boss fights, but the enemy variety on different difficulties is almost enough to make up for it. (there are different enemies that get introduced depending on the difficulty you play!)

I've beaten this game to 100% completion on Hard mode and then ran through it again for New Game + on Nightmare.

Solid 8/10, very very fun!

132356093.review:
I have played this game on its initial release, in 2011, when I wasn’t really aware of American McGee’s work. The game had totally blown my mind. Now, with much more gaming experience and having completed the first game (American McGee’s Alice) I couldn’t really say the same.

The main selling points of the game are undeniably the visuals, music and the atmosphere. 

The scenery of Wonderland are just stunning. Every location has its own unique theme. Even the looks of protagonist, Alice, get different styles, depending on the location she is in. The music adds to the atmosphere of insanity and bizarre (not the level of the first game, cudos to Chris Vrenna, but still). The character design is also very good. Newly added episodes in the real world leave a really bitter taste in your mouth by portraying everything in a very special way – ugly, dirty and unpleasant. Which correlate greatly with colorful imaginable wonderland.

My main problem with the game is combat system. No combos whatsoever. The weapon upgrade system is very plain. Only 2 ranged weapons and 2 melee weapons, one of which is mostly technical – for breaking hidden walls and pushing through enemy’s blocks. Yeah, first game didn’t have combos or anything, but there were much more weapons to choose from (around 9 to 10 or so), even with alternative fire modes! Also, some of the enemies require waiting for them to be damageable, which hurts greatly the flow of combat. 

The collectibles that only adds to the story. Well, the story stuff is great and all, but why not to add a little bonus to exp or smth like that? It would greatly support the motivation for exploration. There is really no point in exploring to be honest. Most of the currency required for upgrading weapons are not hidden or drop from enemies. 

The level design is too straightforward. Platforming sections are very plain and doen’t bring any joy to complete. Most of the NPC interactions share the same paradigm of having one temporary hub and 3 paths with some item to bring back to that character.

While the design of the enemies is great, I’d really love to have more variations of them. And more bosses! Previous game had plenty, why wouldn’t you bring more of them in this one?

The game has many other minor issues like occasional bugs and crashes, mechanics that are not properly introduced and explained and so on.

I cannot really recommend the game, sadly. If you’re a huge fan of American MCgee’s work and his interpretation of Alice in wonderland, you can check the game out for the story and visuals at least. Other than that, I would recommend to skip on this one, as I did on my second walkthrough and dropped the game for good.

-Incapacidad de poner el juego en modo ventana.

-Incapacidad de cambiar la velocidad de apuntado con el raton. La velocidad por defecto es desmesuradamente rapida. (Injugable)
-Incapacidad de cambiar la velocidad de mirar con el stick del pad. La velocidad por defecto es excesivamente lenta.
A este respecto, este punto se combina con el punto siguiente.

132073643.review:
[quote=El Sombrerero]Olvidar es simplemente olvidar, salvo cuando no se olvida. Luego lo llaman de otro modo.[/quote]

Alice: Madness Returns es un juego de plataformas, con algo de combate, en el que se cuenta una atractiva historia de fantasía oscura, basada en los personajes de los libros de Carroll, pero con un tinte mucho más tétrico y adulto.

Jugablemente es, como decía, esencialmente un título de plataformas (con un diseño de niveles realmente bueno), con un poco de [i]Hack and slash[/i] (parte terriblemente penalizada por los dolores de cabeza que da la cámara cuando fijamos un objetivo).

Donde destaca más es, sin ningún género de dudas, en la ambientación. A pesar de que los gráficos no son punteros (el juego tiene más de once años en el momento en que hago esta reseña), la forma de recrear el surreal y maravilloso [i]País de las Maravillas[/i] es simple y llanamente excelente. El buen doblaje al castellano también ayuda a crear esa magnífica atmósfera.

En resumen, se trata de un título que, en lo jugable, tiene el sabor añejo de los buenos juegos de plataformas de hace unos años, y que, solo por lo espectacular de su ambientación, merece mucho la pena. Dura unas 12-15 horas, y suele estar rebajado a menudo.

(*) Jugado en Steam Deck de principio a fin, a 60 FPS estables y sin ningún cuelgue. Solo se necesita un pequeño retoque para que los FPS sean constantes (setear PhysX en bajo).

131735687.review:
I can't even begin to describe how much I love this game, but I'll try my best to do so anyways.

I'll start with my only complaint, that being it can be very buggy and you have to go into the files of the game to optimize and fix some of the buttons, but this isn't that big of an issue, and I can't blame it all that much, since this is a rather old game. Porting games this old isn't exactly easy.

This game I highly HIGHLY recommend. American Mcgee's Alice is by far my favorite version of this story after playing it. The art direction and designs of this game are beautiful and amazing to look at. It can be so pretty, yet so terrifying and dreadful at the same time. I absolutely adore it.

The gameplay, in my opinion, never gets boring. This game knows how to keep you on your toes and always has something for you to explore, especially if you're going for 100% completion. The enemies are great, though some are quite challenging as well.

The story, though gruesome and genuinely frightening, I love it to pieces. The way Alice goes through her memories and mind to find out the truth of what happened to her family is amazing, and when you finally realize who the villain is, it's gut-wrenching to see and hear how truly despicable they are. I had points in my playthrough where I was in shock at how cruel they were and how they were not remorseful in the slightest for their actions. 

Overall, I love this game to death. The design, the story, the soundtrack, the gameplay, in my opinion, it is all spot on. 10/10

And I seriously can't wait for American Mcgee's next entry in the Alice series. <3

131361670.review:
I don't know why people are giving this game such an easy time in reviews, but had I personally understood exactly how buggy it was, I would not have bothered with it.  It's incredibly tiresome.  It's only playable because the progress and success is as equally buggy as the challanges, I feel. I guess there's a chance it's buggier for some more than others?

I have to open the game twice everytime because it always crashes the first time. I have to play with both controller and keyboard because the keyboard got too confusing and non-intuitive, and so as I've switched to controller, some buttons aren't working (such as calling Chesire and going into Hysteria I have to do on keyboard, as well as upgrading weapons with mouse) and it makes the game feel unrelieble, along with everything else that's wrong.   It crashes in the middle of gameplay from time to time, and it's always a guessing game where it got saved last.

Enemies keep bugging out and not dying, sometimes even go entirely invisible, which means I can't progress unless I replay a huge fight.   Dodging and evading is impossible half of the time because body-blocking is apparently the enemies strongest point. Also, Alice apparently forgets her left-and-right from her front-to-back along with her increasing madness, nomatter wether I'm in aim-mode or not.
She also gets stuck in absolute thin air, a lot. As in- anywhere at anytime. Invisible pixels, in or out of fight. Not as in lagging- just suddenly stuck spinning or staring. Usually in corners, door-openings, or uneven but seemingly plain ground.

Things that should NOT happen automatically does, and vice versa, making me feel like I'm not in control of playing/fighting at all. I'm not sure how much of these particular happenings are bugs, or if they're bad control combinations, but something is imbalanced to say the least.

I'm also questioning a huge amount of the content within the game. It feels like most of it was thrown in as an after-thought. Like the flower-painting thing for example? I'll never believe it was suppose to be like that. After 16 hours, I'm also pretty sure the game was suppose to be a lot shorter, but then they extended it and threw in a bunch of lesser well rendered areas. The script in itself is the best part, so I don't mind it being as long as they could make it, but I'm wondering why things feel rushed. 

Conclusion: I don't think they actually finished this game.
 
However, just because I love Alice in Wonderland, and because I'm stubborn, and also because I love most of the visual design in this version, I'll try to finish it.   I don't know if it's a Steam-thing or an old-game-thing but this is horrid on my nerves. 
If you want this game badly- see if you can find it another way first at least, In case it is a Steam-thing.

If they reworked and remastered this game, I would love to play.  But this thing? Never playing again after this, unless I get paid damn well to do it.

131226996.review:
[i] Note: this is a review of both games: 𝘼𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙈𝙘𝙂𝙚𝙚'𝙨 𝘼𝙡𝙞𝙘𝙚 and 𝑨𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒆: 𝑴𝒂𝒅𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔 𝑹𝒆𝒕𝒖𝒓𝒏𝒔. [/i]

                                           ----------------------------------------------------------

[h1] [i] [b] "Seek and ye shall find" they say. But they don't say what you'll find." [/b] [/i] [/h1]

The 𝑨𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒆: 𝑴𝒂𝒅𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔 𝑹𝒆𝒕𝒖𝒓𝒏𝒔 gameplay experience is simply a continuous stream of immense artistical imagery placed right before your eyes.

This game systemizes and improves upon the combat aspect of its predecessor, with upgradable weapons that change visually, combos, and different types of enemies that require alternate approaches. The platforming remains, with new added features that massively improve your enjoyment of the levels.

The levels in 𝑨𝒍𝒊𝒄𝒆: 𝑴𝒂𝒅𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔 𝑹𝒆𝒕𝒖𝒓𝒏𝒔 are other-worldly, each of them is vastly different and hand-crafted to suit the themes and ambience it tries (and succeeds) to convey. I found myself often wondering how the next area would look like, and it still kept surprising me.

The story and lore are a lot more fleshed out than in the first game: there are animated cutscenes, lots of dialogue, hidden memories that fill in the gaps of the story, and character bios. All of this is supported by a great soundtrack and main theme.

The review for this game is short because, honestly, all I have to tell you is that it is amazing. The heart and soul put into this version of Alice is clearly shown all throughout the franchise.

In conclusion:  𝐢𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐝 𝐢𝐭 𝐲𝐞𝐭, 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐰𝐚𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐨𝐫?


[h1] [i] "Is it mad to pray for better hallucinations?"
                   - Alice [/i] [/h1]

                                           ----------------------------------------------------------

[h1] [i] [b] "Wonderland's become quite strange. How is one to find her way?" [/b] [/i] [/h1]

𝘼𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙈𝙘𝙂𝙚𝙚'𝙨 𝘼𝙡𝙞𝙘𝙚 is a great game which went past my expectations.

I initially went into this game thinking it would have a great concept with frustrating gameplay and dull looking levels, but I stand corrected. 

The concept of this game (𝘼𝙡𝙞𝙘𝙚'𝙨 𝘼𝙙𝙫𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙚𝙨 𝙞𝙣 𝙒𝙤𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧𝙡𝙖𝙣𝙙 with a horror twist) is as amazing as I assumed it would be, but the level design and the gameplay was a pleasant surprise — the levels are varied and interesting, and they do not overstay their welcome. I found every level had you spend the perfect amount of time on it, and when the next one came along, it was refreshing. The setting of this game goes from frozen caves, to rivers and forests, to lava castles and more.

What is more is that the soundtracks that accompany these locations are phenomenal and fit the game perfectly — the tracks are creepy, but at the same time wondrous, with great touches like old grandfather clocks ticking sounds marking the rhythm. I really, really enjoyed the music in this game and much of its magic comes from it.

The gameplay itself was also more complex than I imagined it would be. 𝘼𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙘𝙖𝙣 𝙈𝙘𝙂𝙚𝙚'𝙨 𝘼𝙡𝙞𝙘𝙚 is mainly a platformer, but it also includes combat elements — you will find an array of weapons at your disposal, which you can discover throughout your adventure in Wonderland, as well as various types of enemies: from card guards and antlions to fire imps and fish. I have to admit the combat can be a bit messy and unrefined, and the platforming can be slightly annoying at times, but I only had a handful of these moments, and using quick save and quick load you will barely have any issues.

The horror theme of exploring Alice's broken mind through this imaginary world she has created is simply breathtaking.

In conclusion, I found the length of this game to be perfect. It was extremely enjoyable to play, the soundtrack is top notch and the gameplay holds up okay 22 years later. This is a gem of a game that deserves more recognition, with a fantastic art style and design.

131108126.review: Both of American McGee's Alice games are gorgeous art pieces with a unique, horrifying art style that adds to the charm. As games, they're not too good. Finished both titles since from what I understand this port and the EA Origin release are the only official ways to play the original Alice. As stated, the artwork for both super interesting and I love how the soundtracks are more or less horrifying soundscapes, rather than being actual soundtracks. The atmosphere is really well done in both titles, but the gameplay isn't fun in either of them. The original Alice is a sorta fun boomer shooter / puzzle platformer that while sort of enjoyable, aged like milk (minus the art direction, that shines even today). Alice: Madness Returns is a really, REALLY boring hack and slash with repetitive gameplay and almost no depth when it comes to the combat or anything regarding gameplay. Both of these titles are cult classics for a reason, I suppose. If you're one of those super artsy scenecore hipster nerds then sure, you'll probably love this stuff. If you come into these titles expecting something fun, rather than just really cool art pieces (like me), you're gonna think this is really underwhelming. Writing this makes me feel really conflicted since I think everything surrounding these games is super interesting, but they're just not that much fun. If you can ignore the boring gameplay and throw out 30 or so hours of your time without feeling like your time was wasted, go ahead and play these. Definitely never touching either of these titles again, though the presentation and everything these games represent has left an impact on me. Not a massive impact, but I guess something is better than nothing.

130948328.review:
Well, I hate to say that I can only recommend this game provisionally. Alice: Madness Returns is a good game, the story is interesting and the graphics and music are good. This, however, is a bad port. I played this game originally on the PS3 along with the original American McGee's Alice. Got the DLC, played all the way through and even started a second playthrough. It was fun, and when I saw that it was available again on Steam (having been taken down once) I figured, why not?

It is ... pretty annoying to play this on PC. Even after following some guides to tweak settings to be more optimal or take advantage of more modern hardware, things just get weird. If you don't have things set just right, you will [i]consistently[/i] crash at varying places. For instance, lets say you want to remove the 30(ish) fps cap and go up to 60: Well, most guides tell you to add a few extra to whatever setting you're going to use. Thing is, it needs to be only one or two extra. Setting it to 65 like I did caused my game to consistently crash while dealing with a specific section. Likewise, you need to drop your PhysX settings for one specific spot in the game and just that one spot. There are gamebreaking bugs still present if you do certain things in the wrong order. The most egregious issue for me is that you can't run if the camera isn't following you. If the camera isn't positioned juust right Alice will stutter-step and generally move weird which is annoying if not lethal. And the camera controls are a bit wonky, but that may just be my controller settings.

Why did I mark this a recommended? Well, like I said: Its a fun game. Maybe it will run ok-ish if you don't tweak things. Or, maybe you should just copy the tweak guides exactly and not try to fudge things a bit like I did. The game really is fun, and snarky Alice is fun. The combat is action oriented as opposed to the shooter system from the first game. You can move, dodge and eventually block. You will eventually get two melee weapons and two ranged weapons, and a clockwork rabbit bomb that doubles as distraction and exploration tool. The combat is serviceable: It's fluid and relatively fair. Camera issues occur, but it's hard to say if it's just user issues or narrow areas throwing the camera for a loop. 

Exploration is a pleasure marred only by the movement issue I mentioned earlier. The game is beautiful and surreal. The music is a pleasure to listen to and matches well with each area. There are plenty of nods to the previous game (and it's quite easy to add it into this game, that's actually where most of my playtime is from) but there's some explanation of things in the game. You could look up what happened or read a synopsis (there's a bit of exposition available in the Extra Content section of the main menu as well), but it doesn't really affect things too much if you haven't played the original. I found it to be a pretty satisfying game and story, and having figured out most of the ... quirks of this port I'm pretty satisfied.

As a warning for completionists, you'll want to really take your time or use a guide. There's plenty of things hidden in the world that are easily overlooked. Shrink sense can be used liberally to find lots of things, but I still kept missing a few things here and there. It won't affect the ending or anything, and I'm more than happy to give the game another go after awhile to get everything.

130927814.review:
This is a combined review of both American Mcgee's Alice and Alice Madness Returns

American Mcgee's Alice
The story is simple and strait forward, you are Alice a girl who has spent the last decade of her life locked up in a asylum after surviving a house fire that killed both of her parents. 
She must now fight her way through her twisted imagination while coming to terms with the tragedy that took her parents. 
While the graphics are starting to show there age, the level variety is great with a very mixed assortment of locations including Forest, castles, hall of mirror style treatment wards.
My biggest complaint is the combat. First most of the weapons share the same mana pool for ammo forcing you to resort to your slow knife attacks in long fights. 
Second the majority of the attacks in this game push Alice back after she it hit which is fine if your on the ground, but if you at all in the air you will be sent flying usually into the nearest bottomless pit or pool of lava.
While I didn't hate my time I wouldn't make this a selling point.

Alice: Madness Returns
Story wise its fine, better then the first game's plot, but nothing I would sell this game on. Level design is still great, good variety in environments. I do wish levels were a little bit shorter and instead have one or two more stages. Combat is more enjoyable then the first games single ammo bar physics mess, but it is really hurt by the lock on camera moving to terrible angles and Alice's dodging based on how she is facing the locked on enemy and not in relation to the camera itself.

For both of these games I was really expecting more, they are not bad I just feel they fall short of what I feel this series could be. Apparently there is a third game in production called Alice: Asylum; if Spicy Horse can make that ones gameplay really solid then we could have something truly special.

130805612.review:
The story, characters, art and overall vibes of the game are great. The platforming was usually quite fun, but the puzzles are lacking. Where the game really goes wrong is the combat. Like many games, Alice Madness Returns has a targeting system that lets you lock onto enemies. You can switch which enemy you are targeting with the right stick, but YOU CAN ONLY SWITCH TO TARGET AN ENEMY IF IT IS VISIBLE ON SCREEN and even then it often doesn't work. This makes the combat extremely frustrating and sours what is otherwise a solid game. If you're going to play... at least play on easy.

Even so, I was on the fence about whether to recommend this game. However, I decided I can't recommend it because of the litany of issues with the PC version. I encountered SEVERAL crashes and freezes. The game is locked to 30 fps!!! Some menu options are not accessible when using a controller and force you to use a mouse. It's a terrible PC port and the Steam version in particular is not even the complete version! It does not include any of the DLC or the first game bundled with it like some other versions do.

It's worth playing if you can get it for real cheap... but try to avoid the Steam version.

Positive points: It's an awesome and spoppy game and you will love it! The visuals of this game are marvelous, the story is fantastic and so intricate, the soundtrack makes you travel emotionally through the story! Is an incredible game if you like Alice in Wonderland and that little touch of dark. 

Negative points: It's an EA game. What are you expecting if not bugs, not properly executed mechanics? The game will crash a couple times for the weirdest reasons like starting the game, there are many famous bugs (and bless other gamers for figuring out how to fix them and doing EA's work) and some controls are just...maddening. In one part it told me to click the X to shoot...it took me a couple clicks before I realized they did not change a few instructions from console to PC. Good one EA. 

In the end, it's a good game and I definitely recommend! If you are like me and rage quit at the site of platforms, prepare to feel as mad as Alice.

129975887.review: Estéticamente es precioso, su ambientación y banda sonora son excelentes y la historia es profunda y oscura. El sistema de combate a lo hack & slash es muy entretenido y accesible y los escenarios de plataformeo son espectaculares. Alice es genial y su universo es de lo más especial y original (estética steampunk+fantasía oscura= puro amor). He leído que a mucha gente se le crashea y a mí por lo menos solo me pasó una vez (mi ordenador tampoco es que esté pensado para jugar videojuegos), aunque sí es verdad que a veces las armas se traban (aunque le des a click izquierdo Alice no suelta el molinillo de pimienta ni para atrás) o camina sola sin controlarla. La cámara de fijación de enemigos también es un poco meh. Es un juegazo aunque su porteo de consola a pc podría haberse hecho muchísimo mejor. También es una pena que no tenga logros y que no se pueda adquirir su DLC en Steam. De resto, 10 de 10. A pesar de todo, de lo único que me arrepiento con este juego es de no haberlo descubierto antes, se ha convertido en uno de mis dos favoritos de todos los tiempos. Si dudan si comprarlo haganlo, es un juego muy especial y único y la historia no decepciona <3 (PD: No hace falta jugar al primer juego para entender la historia! 129712269.review:
My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. 129640596.review:
Choppy and stuttery on new hardware with no chance to get an update.

And even if you're willing to suffer its technical problems, this is not a good game.
Let me tell you why, but firstly I'll describe some pros:
1. The art is stunningly beautiful. If only this game was a movie, it would be the most bizarre and beautiful movie ever created.
2. Alice's upskirt view is intriguing. She wears many different dresses during the story, each with different skirt and underwear. Some is even comes with see-through camel toe. Normally you can't see it through the long frilled skirt, but there are some places where wind blows from below ;-)
3. Aside bad writing, mediocre acting and very poor direction, the story is interesting and touching.

Okay, that's enough pros, now I'll tell you about what's bad:
1. Controls suck like there's no tomorrow. You're never in control, Alice's always moving on some invisible rails and it some times does not matter what direction you're pressing. If she decides to dodge rigth into a bomb or into abyss, there she goes.

2. Enemies are not meant to be fought but rather solved like puzzles. And there's a lot of repetition and not a lot of options.

3. Ranged weapons look stupid and feel very unpleasant to use. Aiming does not exist.

4. You can not dash-cancel the hobby horse when it feels like you should be able to.

5. Some times, quite often, the hobby horse fails to change the aim between attacks.

6. Graphics were never good for this game and it didn't age well.

129565715.review:
(nostalgia alert)
one of the best games i have ever played!
i played this game a long time ago, and back then it was very dear to me, its story, its characters, and its art. even its music. this whole game is a masterpiece to me.
when i first loaded up the game it was just wow, so much forgotten, yet so much still familiar to me.
i was transported to wonderland and almost wept it was so beautiful and felt great to be back at last!
this is one of my most favourite games in the whole world, and im so glad i get to experience it again! (i originally played on ps3 back in the day!)
this game is still beautiful to me personally, with its Gothic charm, its fantastical fight scenes, and its perilous platforming.

cons: game is dated graphically but still holds its own imo! frame rate is capped to 30 fps (there's a guide to change it in the steam community tab, and audio isnt the best balance imo (some fight scenes are way too loud but just as i remember it tbh)
you also have to use the steam menu to tab out, and upon first launch i did have to task manager my way out of a bug. but all fine after that.
for a game of its age, it performs moderately well in my opinion.
if you are returning to Alice's nightmarish wonderland you shouldn't be put off by the cons, but a newer gamer may not have as good of an experience without the constant drip feed of nostalgia telling you its still wonderful overall.
final verdict:
if you have experienced this game before, and simply want to play again, i highly recommend picking it up, especially if on offer!
and if you have never played it before, i still highly recommend playing, as long as you can put up with a tiny bit of old game jank (it really does hold up well for its age though imo!)
however if you like your games to run at high frame rates out of the box, like fancy 4k graphics and audio that's perfectly balanced then this game regrettably likely isnt for you. if you are able to look past those minor discrepancies, then this game is perfect.

P.S. if you liked this one, check out American McGee's other work such as the Alice before this one.

129557624.review:
They don't make games like these anymore. Alice: Madness Returns is unexpectedly one of the best video-games out there. Not only is the gameplay and level design amazing and there is well over 25 hours of 3D platforming in visually stunning and high-effort creative worlds with mind-blowing music: the story and characters are also extremely present, strong, heart-breaking and immersive.

Obviously the movie Alice In Wonderland is one of the best movies that exists, but this game is TEN TIMES darker. Wonderland is about the darkness, flaws and evil that rooms in the industrialized city life, how absolute evil disguised as pathetic humans scour in every corner and dark back alley. How nothing is safe for an innocent and pure young girl without parents; how everyone is trying to take advantage of you either sexually or financially.

The mind of Alice is the mind of a traumatized and severely abused and manipulated orphan girl. 
Yes , Alice: Madness Returns is dark, your teenage sister was raped and later locked and burnt to death in the room next to you. You thought she was talking in her sleep that night, but no she was getting raped that night before the criminal would start a fire to burn off your whole family. Your entire family has been burnt alive, you were able to escape the home just in time before it burnt down and from a distance you saw the skin melting off your beloved family as they couldn't escape. 

After all this tragedy, at first Alice can't rest because to her it makes no sense how the home could have caught fire. The therapist assigned to Alice suspects Alice herself to have killed her parents and for that reason she has been put into a mental asylum and labelled as a dangerous psychotic woman. After the family tragedy Alice wastes years of her most valuable years scared, lost, locked, lied to and manipulated without family or friends in an asylum for minors. 

The only "friends" Alice has had after her loss have been evil and bitter two-faced people who abuse her and lie to her. Later in the plot you find out that your therapist was involved with burning your home and family down, in fact he was the one who raped your sister and burnt it down. His plans for you was to make you forget everything by becoming your therapist after the crime he committed and to gaslight teenage Alice during therapy sessions for years, to make Alice kill herself and memories with therapy sessions so nothing but a gas-lit soulless poor girl remains to be sold to the city's brothel for a lot of money (self-admitted therapist's plan). 

All of this is told in a mysterious, dark, scary, emotional yet beautiful way. Alice : Madness Returns is a legendary game and despite its older age it has aged super well. This game is a master piece.

"You've used and abused me, but you will NOT destroy me!"
"Save myself from death, is that it? Is that why I've come here? I'm not afraid to die! Times I've welcomed death."
"I want to forget! Who would choose to be alone, imprisoned by their own broken memories?"
"I know their pain. I would assist. But is sanity required for the job?"
~ Alice Liddell

"Threats, promises and good intentions don't amount to action."
"Ah, Alice. We can't go home again. No surprise, really. Only a very few find the way, and most of them don't recognize it when they do. Delusions, too, die hard with memory. Only the savage regard the endurance of pain as the measure of worth. Forgetting pain is convenient, remembering it: agonizing. But recovering the truth is worth the suffering. And our Wonderland, though damaged, is safe in memory... for now."
"Only the insane equate pain with success."
"Only fools believe that suffering is just wages for being different."
"Every adventure requires a first step. Trite, but true, even here."
"Only a few find the way, some don't recognize it when they do - some... don't ever want to."
~ Cheshire Cat

129173820.review:
The game is just bad.
Platforming is fine at its best and broken at its worst. Sometimes you don't know if you reached a platform by mistake or not. I've died many times to the character jumping in the air instead of the platform. The level design is basic and it never really feel like you are smoothly traversing the arena. You always have those bad level design camera to show you where to go as the visual are messy. The animations are basic as well and they are quite ugly during cut scenes.
Combat is just messy and the best way to handle it most times is to cheese the hell out of it. The camera does not help and the locking system does not allow you to handle multiple foes, and they clearly want you to. The attacks from enemies are not always easy to avoid because the dodge mechanics has a weird way to receive input; many times I dodged an attack but the character stayed in the same place instead of going back or on the side. And combat movement is separate from the platforming and you can clearly see how the dodge ability breaks or is inconsistent with traversal.
Hit boxes are a joke for both enemies and platforms. It's so annoying to be able to fight to just been denied because you are 2 degrees too on the left to hit it.
The story is basic and does not necessarily lead you to think for yourself but just wait for the next information that adds nothing to it. And man, so much useless information is provided.
The devs added hours upon hours of the same platforming and puzzles making the experience tedious instead of interesting. If you extrapolate everything that is fine from the game, it would be 1-2 hours long instead of ~12.
I haven't played the original game so I might have missed a lot of references but I don't that could save a mediocre game.
But the worst thing of all is that this game is also quite unstable, crashing randomly and running like crap.
It's locked at 30 fps and feels sluggish, GREAT FOR A PLATFORMER. I also lost 10 mins of progress in 2 occasions because of crashes.
So the point here is, don't buy it. It's not worth your time.
I've only played it as I'm trying to finish the games I have on steam an this was on the top of the list.

128266695.review:
Finally, I had the opportunity to play this game, and although I enjoyed most of it, I encountered minor issues throughout my playthrough. Some of these "issues" are mostly biased, but ultimately, they did not ruin my whole experience with the game.

The best parts of this game are the story and the art direction. Overall, character and level design are superb, and each level brings something new and interesting to see throughout. Complementing its dark theme and tones is the retelling of "Alice in Wonderland" from a darker and more sinister perspective. The story can be quite engaging, but the long levels really took me out at times, and I would occasionally forget about it. With that, my main problem with the game is that most of the levels felt really, really long, and I eventually grew tired of them.

A minor detail was the occasional crash from alt-tabbing, but fortunately no other crashes or bugs were present through my playthrough.

Other concerns would be the fact that you have to tweak some game files in order to get additional content (which DLC weapons no longer work) and boost the game's performance.

Ultimately, "Alice: Madness Returns" was an enjoyable game with a very intriguing storyline and unique style, a game that can be easily picked up by anyone and enjoyed just for the quality of visual stimulation one can find within its hellish representation of Wonderland.

128164817.review:
Curiosa reinterpretación del cuento clásico con un toque bastante más oscuro y tétrico. 
El juego tiene una historia interesante y contada de manera brillante, aunque por momentos, pierde fuelle y da la sensación de estirar el chicle en exceso en algún punto. 
La música está bastante bien lograda respecto a la ambientación aunque realmente no es muy destacable, además está traducido y doblado al castellano. 
El diseño de los niveles pese a ser simplón en jugabilidad (repiten en exceso las mismas mecánicas y a veces da la sensación de hacer lo mismo en otro lugar) sí que están muy bien representados y disfrutarémos en muchos puntos mientras vamos avanzando. Los enemigos cumplen sin más, poca variedad y a veces el sistema de combate a pesar de estar bien pensado se hace tosco cuando hay muchos enemigos en pantalla. 
La duración está bastante bien con respecto a otros juegos del género, ya que sus niveles son largos y cuentas con puzzles, algún boss etc.
Conclusión: A pesar de sus años, ha envejecido bastante bien y sigue siendo un juego muy a tener en cuenta (sobretodo si eres fan) en los juegos de plataformas, además de tener el aliciente de contarnos una historia completamente reinterpretada que irémos descubriendo y su genial doblaje al castellano. Juégalo si eres fan del universo de Alicia en el Pais de las Maravillas o de los juegos de plataformas.

128080350.review:
I like the story a lot, I like how dark and gory everything is. Reminds me of when fairy tales weren't all cute and cheerful, but actually had some darkness to them. Level environments are good too, they go from looking all colorful to looking like Satan's backyard. Gameplay is pretty good albeit towards the middle-end of the game it can feel quite tedious, levels do eventually feel the same in regards to how navigating levels work, combat while being good again does get tedious as the same enemies are thrown around alongside maybe 1 or 2 new enemy in a level, and some levels feel waay too long as if they're dragging them out. Overall the game is really good, I would just recommend also playing this alongside other titles so you can take a breather.

I really would recommend Alice Madness Returns, but just not the PC version if you're the type of person who isn't comfortable/willing to configure multiple ini files. The game does not contain it's dlc out of the box, American McGee's Alice is missing albeit having an option in the menus, game does not run at a comfortable framerate out of the box (unless you're fine with 20-30 fps), you might even encounter a bug where your umbrella doesn't work, and also half the tutorial prompts don't show gamepad ui albeit the other half will making controls confusing for a minute or two in certain areas. If you are comfortable with configuring these then I'd say give the game a shot while it's on sale, it really is good albeit feeling a little tedious. Works great under Linux so anyone using a Steam Deck should be able to play this fine. I also recommend reading these if you do wanna [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2881785983] configure files, restore Alice 1 and DLC [/url] , and this if you need the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2868640315] umbrella fix. [/url]

127899504.review:
This PC port I don't think is as bad as a few people said and nowhere near being among the worst of bad PC ports. There are issues with keyboard and mouse controls, the mouse camera controls are all over the place, aiming is terrible and not what it should be, and there's some glitches including the menu pointer staying on after you exit the menus and go back into game play. However most of this goes away if you switch to controller, so maybe bad news for the keyboard and mouse purists but works fine beyond that.
Game itself shouldn't be missed for anyone interested in dark reimaginings of very old  settings and characters such as this. I do recommend the earlier game first, which sadly can no longer be purchased anywhere (the hack to get it working with this game no longer works for many due to something in modern Windows updates), but if you can manage to play both it is quite the theatrical treat and fantastic additions to Alice's story. The visuals alone of Madness Returns are some of the best of this game's era.
If EA were smart (which they're not), they would release the Complete Edition on Steam. Why they haven't is a true enigma of modern corporate stupidity.

127537991.review:
This game has long been one of my favourites, and I've played it on more than one platform. However, with the Steam edition I have encountered a problem that makes the game literally unplayable past a certain point.

Halfway through the Dollhouse level is a slide that takes you to the second half of the stage. When I reach the bottom of the slide, the level is supposed to be waiting for Alice to simply land on. However, it is not. There's nothing but a black void, that kills Alice when she falls to the bottom. I've tried everything I can think of to fix it. I've gone back to the end of the previous level and played all the way through the Dollhouse again to see if that would help, and it hasn't.

So, while this is one of my favourite game series, and I really hope American McGee succeeds in getting the third game released, because I will definitely play, I cannot recommend THIS version to other players.

127192857.review:
A totally different vibe to the first game, but a very worthy sequel nonetheless.

There are some VERY helpful community guides to help you get the best of this game. The game is quite old now and can understand the original devs taking a step back.

Please make sure you can follow these guides from the Steam page. Improvements are:

1/Smooth 60 fps at 4K (can be tweaked to your monitor settings)
2/No crashing or stuttering (likely to do with cracking the main EXE with Theta patch)
3/DLC weapons and clothing unlocked
4/Alice 1 unlocked (I don't feel too guilty over this as I have the original CD!)
5/Alice 1 upgraded textures
6/Intro videos skipped
7/Umbrella and various other bugs fixed

If you manage to do all the above, the game is a winner!

If you want links, please read Captain Titus' Steam review

Good luck

125809146.review:
Story - Absolute shine here.  A true journey into madness.  Almost felt like i was going mad a bit through the journey.
A full ark with a satisfying ending.

Gameplay - Fun to play and the progression through weapons and upgrades is cool.  Challenging and fun at the harder difficulties.  Mildly repetitive but the story moves it along fabulously.  If you like this style of combat i would recommend lost in random.  You can tell some of the art directors and game play creators are of this kin.

Graphics - I played on 1440p monitor.  Still looks slightly aged but would recommend higher res for sure.  The eerie setting and visuals are stunning and engaging.  Very creative beautiful and sadistically Gothic in a cool way.

Musical Score - Adequate to keep you engaged as you journey through the dark abyss of madness.

Verdict - 9.5 out of 10 What a story!  Cool visuals for the time and engaging enough game play.  Play it great experience!

TLDR: Game is beautiful, story is intresting and atmospheric, but gameplay streches too long and some parts will be boring and monotone - game is often on sale, a -75% usual one is GREAT to pick the game up. Don't bother with full price, I don't think it's worth it.
According to Steam I've played this for the whopping amount of 36.9 hours - ingame timer says 16 hours, 91% completion.
About this game: picked up a copy for a friend to return a friendly gesture and at the same time I bought it for myself, because I was really intrested in it (Alice + implementation of madness? Yes please, I'm in!)
The game starts out wonderful. You'll keep making screenshots - the game world is really nicely designed and well-executed, some landscapes are jaw-dropping both in terms of quality and creativity.
Platforming works great, there are no issues with controls - but after a time it can be boring, because most chapters (5 looong chapters, all in 1-2 different settings than the others) use quite the same mechanics/ideas as precious ones, only re-skinned.
Combat is both lacking and feels rewarding. Why? Personally I really miss combos and airbone attacks. Maybe I'm too new for the third-person platformers, but I think while combat plays a really central part in the gameplay, it could have been much better. And why is it still great? You have 4 weapons - basically a light and heavy variant of melee and ranged. As most things, the weapons look astonishingly good, with real nice sound - and visual effects. But the biggest and best thing of combat system is the really different enemies. They all work in their own way - one is easy to take on with the pepper-grinder (machine gun), the other one's weakness is the heavy Hobby Horse's armor-breaking hits. Each enemy, and especially their mixed groups require different tactics to defeat them. It's a little shame that by the time you finish a chapter, most likely you'll be bored of the enemies - the first Samurai Wasp is challenging, the third is an intresting enemy, but you'll stomp on the 8th one. Not to mention the 20th one.
Level design: Gorgeous. In chapter 2? you'll go into a snowy landscape, to end up in a ship-in-a-bottle, only to get it sunk then continue your journey underwater. Another chapter is all about Japan and the East - koi pond, china-landscape, traditional fans. Chapter 4 and 5 are just incredible and maybe the best ones from the game, both in terms of gameplay and design. If only chapter 2 and 3 would be similarly good.
Though there is one thing that can put a dent on the experience: invisible walls everywhere. You can't touch most of the walls because you'll stop running ~ 30 cm before them, you can't jump on most things because pleasantly placed invisible ~2-3 metre tall "boxes" are placed on them because you only can jump on something you're *supposed* to jump on. It's a shame in a game from 2011.
Minigames! There are various minigames/ tasks in the game you need to complete to continue: chess puzzle, sliding blocks puzzle, shoot 'em up game, sidescrolling platformer, guitar-hero like small puzzles.. I haven't expected this much variation, it's a really strong positive of the game.
Collectibles: Collecting memories gives you a small quote (1-2 sentence) from a specific character of the story that deepens the main story. Even though they are quite conveniently placed and easy to find/get most of them, this makes collecting them really rewarding. Game lacks backtracing at several points of the game, making impossible to get the stuff at the other side of the crossroads if you took the correct one - without chapter selection. What a pity.
Afterall, all I can do is to recommend this game. It has several really strong aspects, while the weakest points aren't worse than "average". Previously I thought it's a silly suggestion, but *Good Guy Nick* is right - playing the game for more than an hour can induce a strong feeling if monotonicity. I feel like most chapters should be 10-20% shorter, because while there are enough action, jumping and fighting to fill the gametime, there is not that much "soul" in the game to keep the gamer playing for longer periods. At the end, it was a nice - after how bad is EA's reputation in recent times, it was refreshing and pleasantly surprising to see a really creative and daring game under their name.
